description:
This simple neighborhood bakery is hands down my go-to spot for my pork buns and cocktail buns in San Francisco!

The pork buns are the perfect balance of salty and sweet and the bread is always golden and fluffy! The cocktail buns have just the right amounts of butter and coconut that melt in your mouth. Most importantly, the buns are always served hot!

Only complaint is that sometimes they run out of pork buns and you have to wait 10-15 minutes for the next batch. But they've always been well worth the wait!
author: Ryan M.

description:
Here's what you want to definitely get from here: Baked BBQ pork buns, cocktail buns, and egg tarts. Those items are exceptional. Although, I'm sure some of their other items may also be pretty good. 

I usually just buy a big box and take it home to share with the family since the shop itself has limited seating and doesn't seem particularly set up to be inviting me to hang around. However, there are usually a group of older Asian men hanging out there and playing games. But, that's not really my scene, but if it's yours... Then you'll feel right at home.
author: Ai E.

description:
Small traditional neighborhood chinese bakery, and one of the best pork bun bakeries around. Just delicious, well balanced sweetness to salty ratio, light and airy and baked to golden brown perfection.

Cash only, walk up counter service, no frills, no fancy signs or valet parking just awesome baked goods. Cheap by comparison, nothing over a couple bucks in the place.

Order ahead of you need more than a dozen or try to get there early as you can- as they are often out by mid morning and waiting for more to come outta the oven. Even if you have to wait it's worth, usually no more than 15 minutes or so. 

A nice variety of different flavored fruit buns, as well as egg custards. An all around solid old school chinese bakery. This little shop is in a busy neighborhood so be aware parking is tricky at different times of the day. I usually stop early in the morning as it is on my route to the SFVAMC.

4 Stars - worth a visit and the pork buns are the best.

00575
author: Ray F.

description:
Come here for the pork buns! BEST IN SF. Be sure to come early in the morning or allot time to wait if you're making a large order. I usually order a dozen pork buns and have to wait 15 minutes or so to have them hot out the oven! The bun is so soft and fluffy on the inside and has a slight crisp on the outside. The pork isn't too sweet or too salty. It's perfection.

This isn't a place where you'll feel pampered and catered to, but you'll get what you want and need -- hot, delicious PORK BUNS!

My dad always makes a special request for me to buy him some when I visit him cause they're that good.
author: Jazzica D.

description: I just stop by the bakery and found out they are on vacation. I really want to try their bbq pork bun again! It was so delicious!
author: Crystal T.

description:
Cash only! I came here because I woke up too late for a sit-down brunch place. I got the pineapple bun and the dinner bun. I thought there would be something inside the dinner bun, but it was literally just a bun for dinner. It was large so I didn't finish it especially since it was just bread. Good, though. The pineapple bun was just sweet enough. It was on the smaller side.

I tried a bite of my sister's winter melon bun and sponge bun. I think her bun choices were better. The winter melon bun had a sticky but sweet filling. The sponge bun was a well made sponge bun. Very soft.

The prices are well priced? I haven't been too many chinese bakeries, but I don't think I saw any buns over $2. This would be a good place to go to if you need something very quick on the go. I might come back to try their other pastries if I am cramped for time again.
author: Helen H.

description: I ordered roasted pork buns and egg tart both were a bit too sweet but still so good. I can only have a little of each but my boyfriend can eat non stop  i tasted a little coconut so that gave it a little difference between others. There was no line when i went around 12 pm. The employee was nice, poked the little holes in the box because everything we ordered was fresh out the oven. Deff stop by if you are around
author: Joyce T.

description: Probably the best don tots in the area without having to travel all the way to china town. Also their buns are great quality. Highly recommend the cocktail bun!
author: Eric L.

description: I wouldn't come here for the ambiance but the custards and pastries are inexpensive and quite tasty!
author: Helen z.

description:
Got one of their delicious egg custards for $1, it was really good because it wasn't too sweet, it was perfect flakiness and had everything that was right for this egg custard! This is a small Chinese bakery and it's really cute and sales all the Chinese bakery essentials, but I only came for the egg custards because I heard they were good here.

When I ate the egg custard it was a bit soggy, wet but that might be the style of the egg custard and the fact that I held it in my bag for a while (30 minutes) while I walked around. I'd be excited to come back and try the other things they sell here.
author: Christopher L.

description: I stopped here based on Yelp reviews but I ended up disappointed.... I only ordered Pork Bao and Almond Cookies and both were average at best. The almond cookie practically disintegrated in my hand - way too crumbly. I probably lost half of it. The Bao filling was not very sweet - I prefer it more flavorful. This was kind of meh. The worst part, though, was the overwhelming smell and taste of Crisco. They must use Crisco to make the tops of the buns shiny, but that's all I could taste. ICK. Parking is VERY difficult here and they are tearing up Clement which makes it even worse. CASH only here too - remember that!!!
author: Wanda G.

description:
Had high hopes, but big let down. The lady behind the counter was nice but the quality is not what I expected.

The egg custard was too watery and overly sweet (more like yellow sugar water) and a few had a slight crunch to it (I'm guessing it must be the egg shells). The "old wife cookie" was a mess. it crumbled when you bit into it and was lumpy instead of a smooth sweet paste.

The place is packed so they do have their fans, but it's not my type of place.
author: Eric T.

description:
I highly recommend the pineapple bun, roast pork bun and egg tart! The pineapple bun crust is perfectly baked and has incredible flavor. The roast pork bun was fresh and contained slices of BBQ roast pork - good quality for $1.40! The egg tart had a super thick custard filling. All pastries were served hot! 

The ambience is very traditional Chinese bakery with middle aged to old Chinese men playing chess. One side of the cafe is dedicated to chess players and the other side for those looking to enjoy their pastry and coffee/tea.

Enjoy!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Their BBQ pork buns are our favorite.  Dropped by today only to find they're on vacation & closed until 10/2/18!!   So 5 stars for BBQ pork buns but wish they updated their Yelp page.
author: Lisa K.

description:
This has been my 'go to' place for Don Tots (egg custard tarts) and Cha Siu Baos! Why pay $2 or wait in line at GG in Chinatown...THIS place has don tots just as great and super satisfying! 

- Don Tot:
     - VERY flakey crust (i hate the hard doughy kind) and doesn't leave a weird after taste in ur mouth. 
     - Custard is not hard, not runny, it's perfect! Super amazing especially if u eat it when it's warm! 

-Cha Siu Bao (baked version):
     - Perfectly browned goodness
     - The pork is cut better than bite size (which i like)... most other baos have bite size, but it's always a larger piece that will take u forever to chew ... this bao has the perfect pork n gravy ratio throughout the bao. Don't ask me why,  but when ur near the end and have all bao left n no more gravy or pork, it's sometimes a bummer ... but as always somethings must come to an end lol.

     I 've been going here every couple weeks on weds for bout a year ... and i thought it was about time i did a review.  The lady who helps me is super nice and is always pleasant. She doesn't care that i give her my order then ask to put a bao in a separate bag cuz imma bout to scarf it down as i drive home lol
     I finally decided to do a review because today,  i called to c if they had any of the two items left in stock.  She asked me how many and what time and poof she had them ready for me when i got there in 10-15 minutes. 
    Im pretty picky when it comes to don tots n cha siu baos ... hope this place stays consistent forever!
author: LM J.

description: This place is awesome!  The best bbq pork bun I have ever had.  All the buns are really great though.  Go early they do sell out.
author: Amanda L.

description:
Lung Fung is a hidden gem in the Outer Richmond that deserves to be known by more people. Yes, their hours aren't great. Yes, the smell of smoke outside the restaurant occasionally gets to bother you. But it's worth it.

For change you can find under your couch cushions, you are greeted with some of the most warming, delicious baked char siu bao and other baked goods you could ask for, from some of the nicest women who are so glad to see a new face step into their tiny little store.

It really is a magical little place. Great food, with a whole lot of culture wrapped in it with all of the men playing Chinese chess on the tables up front. They say they specialize in wedding and birthday cakes, and maybe I'll have to try them out some day.
author: Griffin S.

description:
Lung Fung has changed owners since ~Summer 2015. The nice lady behind the counter is no longer there, maybe "retired."

...Sadly, the buns are no longer the same....The bread is too thick, too sweet, and not as chewy as before. The BBQ Pork filling is now much less and the flavoring is slightly off. ...pricing seems to have gone up to $1.2 each now...

...what a bummer....
author: Derek S.

description: I got addicted to their pizza bun with cubes of hot dog, mayo, sauteed onions, and crunchy bun.  It's so good.   Their bbq bun is just number one with just enoigh gravy.  Egg tart is anotherr favorite.
author: Helen L.

description:
Egg tarts to die for.. get them fresh from the oven . Yum.I brought them to a friend post op who was craving egg tarts.  Everyone was asking where I got them
they were so good!
author: lily r.

description: Bakery items taste good, so I'm rating 3 for the food. I go for their wife (melon) cakes but beware! The worker used a calculator to add up my 5 items ($6.70) and charged me $7.20. I asked if the extra .50 was tax and she looked at me blankly like she couldn't hear me. However, to go items and bakery items should NOT be taxed,  per California sales tax law. I paid cash and no cash register was used.  I find other Chinese bakeries do this as well, as if you can't do the math, and they generally get away with it.   I know it was a small difference so I let it go, but I'm sure they do this to a lot of customers.
author: C C.

description: Pretty good egg tart, though the crust could have been crispier, and pineapple cream bun.
author: Ellen L.

description:
Servant:  My Lord, what was it the barbarian said, as the riders vanished?
Master LI:  Omnia mutantur, nihil interit. Everything changes, but nothing is truly lost. 
Neil Gaiman - The Sandman

These streets were old when I was young and first walked upon them.  Streets here had such cool names.  We walked to Fulton St or Clement St depending on what bus we needed to take.  My mom flew my brother and I up to visit our aunt during winter break.  So cold.  I had never been so cold before and I got sick.  Living in San Diego I had never been exposed to temperature extremes before.  Still the vacation was awesome.  There were awesome sights to see such as the Golden Gate Park and Seal Rocks and delicious Chinese food to eat.  Better than any found in San Diego.

Now I take my kid to San Francisco each summer to visit my aunt and to eat delicious Chinese food.  Jennifer O. said I would find the best baked cha siu bao in San Francisco at Lung Fung Bakery on Clement St.

I walk with my kid down Clement St. like I did when I was a kid.  People are nice here.  There are many delicious looking baked goods but I came by to try the baked cha siu bao.  They were fresh and hot from the warming oven.  Slightly sweet flavor from the pastry nicely complimented the delicious bbq pork filling.  This is one of the best baked cha siu bao I have ever had.  We will be back for our walk down these old streets next summer for more cha sui bao.
author: Soo H.

description:
I wanted a quick spot to pick up baked pork buns, egg tarts, sponge cakes, wives cookies, curry half moon pastries, and pineapple buns-yummy goodies!!  and I found this great hidden place! Of course I Yelped this and am not disappointed. 
A very nice gentleman and woman helped me with the order of 7 boxes (I would of bought more but I was too late in the day- my fault) ...they were wonderful and gracious in helping me with my selection. It was a good feeling establishment. When I walked in people were playing cards chatting it up and buying lottery tickets just my type of place! I will definitely go back again and again!! Thank you Yelp and its followers who lead me there.
-Stephanie
author: Stephanie T.

description: My coworker occasionally brings in their delicious pineapple buns. By lucky chance, I moved to a place around the block from them. Their pineapple buns are some of my favorite pastries I have ever had! Hot dog bun is delicious too, can't wait to try more :)
author: Serena C.

description:
I made it! I finally made it while they were still open! That makes my 4th try and I am so glad I did. Got my four boxes ready to do my Santa drop off. Of course, I ate two ham and egg and one charsiu bao first. OMGGG!!!! My mouth is so happy. Best morning cheap eats. I think I need to walk a few miles now. 

Small bakery shop owned by a couple. I had called in my ordered the day before and was happily greeted by a male. Arriving by 9am the next day I didn't think my order would be remembered or even mattered since the store was light on patrons and it was early.

To my surprise, after mentioning my name to a lady she had recited my order accurately! This couple is amazing, hardworking and talented.

The lady was cheery and nice. Even when she told me, "no more boxes, ok?" she said it with a smile so I accept her answer. 

I had to wait for my final box and she even allowed and encouraged me to take the first three boxes to the car without paying! 

Her mannerism reminds me of my Mama L (RIP). She may not be aware but simply seeing her face this morning had added a smile to my face. 

Happy Sunday, everyone. Live, love and shine your light. 

What you need to know:
Cash Only
Not open on Mondays
You might get lucky and be offered complimentary coffee
Street parking
Down the street from Honey B
They offer Chinese chess for you to play while you're on your snack break
The front of the shop says they specialize in cake but I didn't notice any cakes inside
The flow is very frequent so you will see many locals stop by for a fresh bun every few minutes
author: Jess N.

description:
Oh my gosh, go to Lung Fung bakery for the "best in the City" BBQ pork buns and the piping hot, creamy egg custard tarts that'll send you right to heaven.

According to Yelpers in the know, get there before 4pm when they might sell out of both- or satisfy yourself with coconut cream-filled pastries and other things you want to eat. 

Everything looks delicious.

Trust me when I tell you this: If you don't live in the nabe, the quick trip to 20th & Clement is worth it. 

The service is beyond cheerful and friendly.

Cash ONLY.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
First things first...Lung Fung has 4.5 stars on Yelp.

A Chinese eatery. With a Yelp rating greater than 4 stars.

It must be extraordinary.

It seems Lung Fung is best known for two items: their $1.10 CHA SIU BAO, a baked BBQ pork bun, and their $0.80 DAN TAT, or egg tart.

Their baked cha siu bao (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lung-fung-bakery-san-francisco?select=lpnL0bcUD1_dvT1x83P8yA#ZsV8eI1eXKKY3TKMWGUCeA) is pretty dang good. The bread tastes eerily similar to regular white bread, so it doesn't have the sweet pineapple-bun-esque crust that I prefer (thanks for elevating my standards, Tim Ho Wan). If you get one fresh out of the oven, it'll be full of piping hot, stickily sweet sauce enveloping fatty pieces of BBQ pork. Divine.

As for the dan tat, I wasn't that impressed (though my friends liked it). We got fresh ones that were straight from the oven--burn alert! The custard is generous, creamy, and subtly sweet, and is portioned well with the amount of crust (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lung-fung-bakery-san-francisco?select=lpnL0bcUD1_dvT1x83P8yA#lDLX2KF1PownyWjiU3GFeA). But, I have gripes with their crust, which is of the typical flaky style. Lung Fung over-baked the outer edges, leaving a burnt taste with every bite. Perhaps it was just this batch, but you can definitely see the darkened edges in the picture. That easily overpowered the delicate custard taste. Also, Tai Cheong spoiled me by introducing me to a sweetened, crumbly crust style, but, don't fret, I'm basing my opinions relative to my experiences in the states.

Authentically, English isn't the strong suite here, and it's CASH ONLY. Prices are cheeeeep (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lung-fung-bakery-san-francisco?select=lpnL0bcUD1_dvT1x83P8yA#lpnL0bcUD1_dvT1x83P8yA), and there is probably a gaggle of elderly Chinese men crowding around a table playing mahjong or Chinese chess.

Their CHA SIU BAO is worth a shot; as for the DAN TAT, I'm still a Golden Gate Bakery believer.

Extraordinary? I would shorten it to ordinary. But it's still pretty darn good P:
author: Adele F.

description: Pork buns are excellent!!  Maybe a little too sweet for me, but sooo good.... Also, the pastries are very authentic and really good.  Service is quick and to the point.  Nothing fancy here, just some good basics.
author: Michael Z.

description: Ordered the pineapple bun and egg tart.. pineapple bun had a weird after taste and the egg tart tasted like it was 2 days old.. when I got it, it was cold.
author: Justin M.

description:
The BBQ pork buns are a MUST!! I love that the bakery keeps the buns warm and not out on display, so when you bite into it, it feels like it just came out of the oven.

The BBQ pork bun itself is amazing - moist, savory bbq pork encased in soft, fluffy pastry. It's super cheap too - only $1.10 each.

Pro tip: If you buy two BBQ pork buns, also get a egg custard for $0.80 - comes out to an even $3. That way you don't have any loose change in your pocket :)
author: Yuan J.

description:
Love, love Lung Fung. It's a small, hole in the wall Chinese bakery lounging around on Clement. There's a large selection of various pastries to get, but what you really want to opt for are the pork buns. They are $1.10 each, and the lady/auntie who is there every morning (except today!) usually throws in a couple free ones. 

The pork buns are really good and addicting. They're baked and more bbq-y than you typically find at most dim sum places. So get a couple or a dozen and throw in some egg tarts as well!
author: Jonathan Y.

description: I consider myself a Char Siu Bao connoisseur having grown up in SF and having tried them from bakeries all around the city. These are some of the best. Quality ingredients and not a lot of fat in the meat. Also enjoyed a bunch of other items. We had a vegetarian with us who enjoyed the "dinner roll", which is basically the Bao dough with no filling. All great.
author: Derek C.

description:
I stopped by after a short urban bike ride to check out their curry pie ($1.50) because a bike ride is the perfect excuse to stop for a snack. You need energy, right? The pie wasn't that big but it was pretty perfect - flaky crispy crust with a mild curry filling, not overwhelming or too strong. I also tried the BBQ pork bun ($1.10) for comparison but it wasn't as good as Wing Lee down the street. The filling was more goopy and the bun when bitten into just got mashed down. Hubby got a a giant almond cookie (60¢) which was nice but a little dry.

Good value but stick to the curry pie here.
author: Jean K.

description:
The Baked BBQ Pork Buns here are great! Packed in this perfectly toasted bun is a good amount of fluffy bread and a load of delicious meat. The meat is complemented by a sauce that isn't too sweet or overpowering.

This visit was part of a 6-person BBQ Pork Bun Crawl to a bunch of San Francisco's most popular bakeries. To read up on other bakeries we visited, check out my Yelp list: http://www.yelp.com/list/bbq-pork-bun-crawl-sf-san-francisco.
author: Mark C.

description: The BBQ pork bun was to die for. The sponge cake was really good too but the egg custard wasn't anything special. The coffee was terrible. I would go back for the savory pastries though.
author: Claudia G.

description:
Great service! The lady at the counter was super sweet and helpful. 
I got spam and egg bun, coconut tart, walnut cookie, almond brittle covered by chocolate, winter melon cake. 
Loved them all except the coconut tart, highly recommend the walnut cookie and almond brittle with chocolate. 
P. S.: The huge walnut cookie was fresh out of the oven and oh so delicious!
author: Jane L.

description: This place was so slow in terms of service,and the lady was so rude to me putting things in plastic bags instead of a box ,i had to ask if she had a small box before she gave it to me.She then made stacking the baked goods so complicated. And so for my last 2 egg tarts i just asked for a bag,even though i knew it be crushed easily. When I asked for a bag to hold all my stuff she gave this frustrated response and attitude to me so never going there again !Rudeness
author: Jessica S.

description:
I've been coming to this little gem for well over 20 years for the best cocktail buns in the city. They're best eaten straight outta of the oven with a cup of Joe in my opinion. Also try the barbeque pork buns for a savory twist, pineapple buns, egg tarts, and sponge cakes. 

*The sweet lady (Fung) behind the counter recently retired., but the new owners seem to run the business in a similar manner as she did.
author: Jim Y.

description: So delish, so cheap. My faves: egg custard, bbq pork bun. You can get a feast for like $10.
author: Nick S.

description: Great Dan tat (egg tart), curry puff pastry, and pineapple bun here! Woke up the happy cantonese kid inside of me. :) great for breakfast and the staff (Angela) was very nice.
author: Penny W.

description: This place became kind of inconsistent the last couple of times I came here. The pork buns were too bready without much filling and were missing some of chewiness from before. Also the egg custard tarts were kind of soggy and not fresh. I'm not sure if they changed owners or bakers, but this place is just not the same as before.
author: Henry W.

description: Get the BBQ pork buns! A steamed version would be great. Good sauce, good amount of meat, soft bun. Egg tarts were flaky and large but that means a lot of custard making the ratio of custard to egg a bit off from what I'm used to. Pineapple custard bun had thick pineapple crust and was a bit hard. The custard had good flavor, not too sweet. The sponge cake had a nice spongy texture but was bland for me.
author: KoKo K.

description:
Best BBQ buns! My husband found another new favorite---pineapple w custard buns!
There are a must try!:-)
author: Cheeleng S.

description:
BEST BAO IVE EVER HAD. 
So my boyfriend and I come to San Francisco every four months for vacation and on one trip we tried to find the best BAO, and this place won by a long shot. Try to come in the early morning because that's usually when it's freshly made. Also, try the egg tarts because they're great! Unfortunately it's cash only but it's totally worth every penny!
author: Miranda A.

description: My first visit here and the yelp reviews are right on the mark with the BBQ buns and the egg custard tart. The dough of the BBQ bun is very light with a greasy air like quality. Normal buns have more of a substance and is heavier. This bun makes a good light snack on the go. The meat and sauce are flavorful. The egg tart filling is "wow" factor and stands out very well in taste and smooth texture; however, I wanted the crust to be a little thicker. I almost came across a perfect egg custard. I was so close and yet so far! LOL All in all it is a good bakery in this part of the city.
author: Priscilla L.

description: Another great find. Thanks yelp! I've been here several times and finally getting a chance to write this review. The lady running the front knows all her customers and is very friendly. Their buns are cheap! I bought 3 BBQ pork buns and 2 custard tarts for under $5! What a steal for the quality I'm receiving. I will be a regular ;)
author: Liz N.

description: Nice place,Recommended!! I very like it.egg tart it was my favorite, Delicious,also the barbecue pork buns is best of the city
author: Yan Z.

description:
I've been passing by this bakery for three years, and it wasn't until recently that I saw the Yelp reviews.  I can't believe I've passed one of the best places to get pork buns in the city!  I also can't believe there isn't a line out the door all the time..

I went this past weekend and, once again, my fellow Yelpers did not disappoint!  The bread on the bun was sweet, and the pork inside was balanced between sweet and savory.  I also got a pineapple/red bean bun, it was delicious too.  And the total price was less than $3.

Plus, the woman who helped me was super friendly and had a big smile on her face at 8am.  So I'm definitely coming back for the welcoming atmosphere and for the affordable, yummy buns.
author: Vira P.

description:
Food:
-Small selection of typical asian baked goods
-$1 per medium-sized freshly baked bbq pork bun, it is what it is

Service:
-Old asian lady who actually smiles instead of glowers

Setting:
-I felt like I walked into a traditional chinese public bathhouse full of old asian men sitting around socializing and drinking tea except they had clothes on (thank god)
author: Tian Q.

description:
I have been eating a lot less starchy foods as of late , BUT , after running some errands in the Richmond during the afternoon this was to tempting a change of pace , 

The one thing Lung Fung has nailed is the filling that actually has no cheap fillers , its just pure quality and goodness ,  

That said , the buns were not as I am used to and lacked the Puff that one expects 

Was a good lunch, and will return again
author: Joseph A.

description: I love this place! Their pastries are fresh and warm when you buy it. They have all of my childhood favorites.
author: Bonnie S.

description: My new favorite place for Dan Tat. You know the popular custard tarts that everyone clamors for at that other Chinatown bakery? These just as good! I've had a few other items that were also very good, winter melon cake, curry pastry, pork bun to name a few. Family owned, really nice people.
author: Ken T.

description: Ok walk in.. Is not much assorted bake goods.. Oh no dim sum too.!! Or rice soup !! But my egg tarts n BBQ pork buns are fresh hot..!! Ok when back in and bought any 20 BBQ pork buns !!
author: Crisy G.

description: first time i've ever had a pork bun, and i went back three times in one week. absolutely delicious. always fresh, soft, and sweet. and what a deal. got a pineapple custard bun later and it was fine. not a whole lot of custard, but I also had never had them before. I have gone out of my way to take people here. They do run out of some of the buns if you go too late in the day, but I have never seen them out of the pork buns. the ladies there are so nice too!
author: Elizabeth H.

description: My fave oven baked pork buns in the Richmond and tasty pineapple custard buns. Always friendly service, too! Can't get that everywhere at other dim sum/bakery spots
author: nancy l.

description:
We happened upon this gem on Clement Street because we were on Geary and didn't want to drive through the city to Chinatown for bbq pork buns. We turned to yelp and this place was near. It's a small Chinese bakery and on the day we were there, two tables of Chinese chess were being played by old Chinese men. 

The bbq pork buns were kept in a warmer and we devoured the 8 we bought. Yes, 8 at $1.10 each. Egg tarts were fresh out of whatever is used to cook them and we got 6 of those. So delicious. No need to fight through the crowds on Chinatown for ok bun. Go out here and get the most delicious BBQ pork buns and if you are lucky, you get fresh egg tarts.
author: Siu-Henh C.

description:
holy bbq pork buns. holy. bbq. pork. buns. 

this place is absolutely incredible. it doesn't hurt that our order was pulled fresh from the oven. I've never experienced anything like it. can't wait to come back and try more on their menu!

did I mention it was only $1.10/bun??
author: Venice P.

description:
I've grown up on this place! If there's a pink box on my kitchen table when I wake up one morning, it's definitely from here! My dad had been a customer for practically my whole life or something (I'm 20 now) and the only time he doesn't get coffee here is when they're closed or something. Every who goes there is a regular because the staff is so friendly and welcoming (they're all Chinese). Sometimes I can go there to get something and if I don't have money, the owner will just let me have it and my dad will pay for it the next morning he goes (: hahah They're definitely the type to remember you if you go there often enough...

I love their buns, tarts, everything... if I crave Chinese pastries, I want them from here! Maybe I'm bias because I've eaten here for so much of my life, but their "boh loh baos" and sponge cakes are definitely one of my faves, along with their BBQ pork buns and egg tarts. MmMmm, goodness! The fruit cakes are good too! Man, I'm craving this place now...
author: Angie Y.

description:
Prior to my char siu bao experience at Lung Fung's, I thought they all tasted the same- meh.  How wrong was I? Very.  

Because the BBQ pork buns here are absolutely delicious! I was never even a fan until I tasted these bad boys.  All it took was one bite of the warm, flavorful and abundant filling, and I was sold (see photo). Also, the lady that works there is super friendly, a nice change from the standard workers at most other bakeries. The only other item I've had here was the cocktail bun (which the lady recommended since they don't make mexico buns) and it was just okay.

Bottom line?- CHAR SIU BAO! CHAR SIU BAO! CHAR SIU BAO!
author: Mimi S.

description: Delicious. Tasty BBQ pork bun, yummy cookies and very friendly staff. Where else can you get a filling lunch and dessert for under $5.
author: Michael C.

description:
OK, so you don't see very many mexicans in chinatown.  Infact, I think the triad wipes out us vatos, so I typically try to avoid.  But Clement Street ain't chinatown, so I feel relatively safe that jackie chan won't kick my ass when I roll my 8-4 impala through there to get me sum dim sum.

Lung Fung is bad ass!  My mom once got conchas and filled them with carnitas.  I was about 6 and it was the best think I ever tasted.  Well that feeling came back when I tried the Char siu bao at Lung Fung.  Take a bow, lung fung....literally, take a bao!  Most chinese bakeries use cat when they make their bao.  No lie.  Ask any gringo lady 65 or older who lives alone in the bay area.  She has probably lost at least one house cat under mysterious circumstances.  And you know where they end up.  General Cho's food processor.  The meat in these 'pork' buns is usually musky smelling and full of cartilage, fat, bone and other connective tissue.  They cover this up by pouring in too much sweet & sour sauce, ruining the whole thing.  Not Lung Fung.  Their bao is on!

Now lets talk about desserts.  Their egg tart is AWESOME!  I can never go back to mamita's flan now that I've tried this.  A light, eggy custard.  More white than the typical yellow tarts you'll find in chinatown.  A little less sweet, but that's because they're not trying to hide imperfections in their baking process.  The crust is soooo light and flakey.  To my Mexican brothers who want good chinese dim sum, forget chinatown.  Roll down Clement and stop by Lung Fung.
author: Nacho L.

description:
Decent little chinese bakery with awesome pricing- think a little over .50 per item. BF popped in while I was in a meeting nearby and surprised me with treats afterward- an egg custard and a coconut cream bun. Both were light and tasty, and above all, cheap.

Large selection, employees don't speak much english- basically enough to order from menu or point at case and pay. Not really much else needs to be said anyway, right?

Bottom line: cheap Chinese pastries. Wish I'd come when bbq pork buns were available.
author: Stefany V.

description: 5 stars for the baked bbq pork buns.  I haven't tried anything else here, though may never have to as long as they keep making the baked pork buns the way they do.  Everything about them are great.. quality of the bao, and pork filling.
author: Mark M.

description: Reminds me sharply of a bakery in Hong Kong. The buns were nice and warm. The server was very friendly though slightly pushy to try and get me to get other buns I wasn't very keen on. I really like their bbq pork buns.
author: Han Teng W.

description:
Lung Fung brings back memories of  their savory  bbq pork buns(1).  sadly, the shelves were bare of pork buns. only custards and other buns (.90) remain. no interest in sweet buns today.

lung fung is also a social center for some seniors playing chinese chess.  (looks like checkers, played like chess with quaint rules)..

didn't leave empty handed, got a tsing tao paper (.60). them almost all gone too.

probably cssh only.
author: Victor G.

description: I'm pretty obsessed with cha siu bao, and I've been all over chasing down these little pork buns. In all the cities and all the shops, this is one of my favorite of all time. First time I've ever had them with a deep caramelized crust on the bottom, which in no way hampered the fluffy gorgeous bread all around. Nice hunks of pork, too. Excellent!!!
author: Heather M.

description: I have been trying to find an alternative to Golden Gate Bakery for years, and Lung Fung Bakery came very close. The egg tart was nice, creamy, but not too sweat. The crust was a little more crispy than the ones from Golden Gate Bakery. Bake BBQ bun was very good as well. However, it seemed to be more doughy than I would like. Given the egg tart costs half as much as Golden Gate Bakery. I would definitely come here whenever I go to Sunset district :-)
author: Ka C.

description:
+ Baked BBQ pork buns (char siu bao). @(*$&^ delicious
+ Egg tarts ftw

I yelped and I found. Just what I was looking for: nondescript HK-style bakery selling diet-unfriendly deliciousness. Came at around 4pm on a Saturday afternoon. Cantonese gramps were playing Chinese checkers and making a small ruckus at a sunbathed table by the window. I saunter in and liquidated the rest of their egg tarts, and had the good fortune of being greeted with a freshly baked batch of pork buns. I'm pretty sure you can get fat just by breathing in the aroma of freshly baked char siu bao. 

Egg tarts: $0.70/each, flaky pastry, not-too-sweet custard
Baked BBQ pork buns: $1.00/each, fluffy bread, generously stuffed with salty-sweet bbq pork

I walked out with 10 egg tarts and 6 pork buns. $13 total for all that decadence? YES. OH YES!
author: Megan L.

description:
I just started using Yelp recently and Thank God I did. All of your reviews pointed me to the best pork bun shop in SF,Lung Fung Bakery. We took a short drive from Seaside Ca to the city(115 miles) and arrived around 2:30pm to the bakery. We were greeted by the before mentioned "nice old lady" who knew exactly what we wanted...pork buns and egg tarts. It was kind of eerie. My girlfriend even asked if I had been here before and I assured her I had not. 10 pork buns and 5 egg tarts later we are sitting in the car ready to bite into our first pork bun and oh wow, it's like we ate a piece of Heaven. A good hamburger is my favorite food but this was right up there,by far the best pork bun I had ever had! They should try selling these things at the Giants games,can you imagine? So good we had to have another just to make sure it wasn't a mistake and ok now we want desert and that egg tart is looking pretty good too and oh wow,another piece of Heaven. So then we realize that we don't have enough to share with friends and family so we go back in and there's only 5 left,so we buy those and 5 more egg tarts. I made up a phrase for the next time we go to Lung Fung and you all have my permission to use it for whenever you're in the mood for that piece of Heaven, whenever you go to Lung Fung just say,"It's time for a pork bun run"ha!
D.T.
author: Darrell T.

description: Had a sudden craving of pork buns and yelped a few places and this had the best reviews. Came in at 830am and lady was super sweet and their pork buns are amazing,especially when they're fresh! She offered me to buy coconut buns and I caved in and bought it! By the way, it was yummy! Definitely coming back!
author: Janice B.

description:
My FAVORITE Baked BBQ Pork Buns ($1).

Evar.

p.s. I would not recommend the egg tarts.
author: Jess C.

description: I was really disappointed since I didn't get there until pretty late in the day and there weren't any baked roast pork buns or egg tarts left.  Nevertheless, I ordered the steamed bbq buns and the steamed lotus paste buns.  Not bad.  Will definitely go back the next time in the area and will make it a point to get there earlier in the day to get the baked bbq roast buns and the egg tarts.
author: Susan C.

description: Just went back to buy some egg tarts.  To my surprise, every item has been raised by 0.10. Only a dime more.  Only tea and water remains the sand price.  Still good.  Everything is $0.80 cent on upwards to $1.10 with the exception of Pineapple bun and Cocktail bun which is priced at 0.60 cents.
author: Jack L.

description: Their cha siu bao is sooo yummy. The bread is perfectly chewy and the filling is flavorful! When it comes hot out of the oven, there's nothing more you can ask for. The egg tarts are also delicious and prices are reasonable.
author: Kerry N.

description: The bbq pork buns are sooooo good. It's one of the best ones I've had in the city so far. I come here after work and I pick up three buns for like 4 dollars and - bam there's dinner. Love this place
author: Irene L.

description: I got the BBQ pork bun and egg tarts. Both were really good. I prefer this place over Golden Gate Bakery. There is plenty of street parking, no waits out the door, and the cashier is wayyyyy nicer.
author: Krazilaughter S.

description:
My latest string of odd experiences eating in restaurants has taken me back to places that I'm familiar with. As someone who eats like a hog, I'm not only looking for good food, but the entire experience matters to a great deal. This morning I came back to Lung Fung and with a sigh of relief as there were no odd incidents to report. Not only were they open, I got to try their fresh baked bread and every bite was a heavenly treat. To me, these Chinese sweetbreads are the best and cheapest breakfast items for those who are trying to cut back on a gut busting meal so early in the morning. 

Now, you all know how I like them, fresh, soft and sweet! Since I already know about their best--yes the best--dan tat and coconut bread, I opted to change things up by trying their humongous red bean and custard sweetbread at 70 cents each. They both came with a layer of sugary cookie dough on top and the texture and sweetness were on point with a nice mix of crunchy-mushy consistency that had me begging for more.

The bread itself was warm and super soft with naturally sweetened red beans and thick custard fillings. The only thing I wished could be better was having more fillings inside as my treasure hunt was short lived. Contrary to my previous visits, the ambiance was a bit subdued as the chess players were still waiting for their partners to arrive. Too bad they don't make taro bread here, but I would love to come back to get another round of dan tat and to try their delicious looking coconut tarts. 4 stars for the experience.
author: Daniel L.

description:
No. 

We drove 1.5 hours to get here based on the yelp reviews. 

Very disappointing. Tasteless. We have better here in San Jose. 

Enough said.
author: nikki v.

description: All you need to order are the BBQ Pork Buns (Baked Cha Siu Baos).  They are the best in town.  Kinda hard to find parking, but since there's almost never a wait, I often park in the driveway next door (leave the car running), while I run in to order at least half a dozen.  I almost always order a few when I'm in the neighborhood.  My most recent order at almost 6 on the Saturday before Xmas was 10 buns for $10.  Yum!
author: Christina L.

description:
Rare story of fantastic customer service at a Chinese establishment:

Went to Lung Fung Bakery at 630 thinking it closed at 7. Shopkeeper opened up for me and I ordered these pastries. When I tried paying with card turned out it was cash only, and I had 0 cash on me, so he ended up just gifting me the pastries. Add the fact that they are delicious and he's now got a loyal customer for life!
author: Neil L.

description:
Best baked pork buns ive had! I always seem to come at perfect time when they have fresh out the oven pork buns! Warm, soft, chewy with right amount of meat and sauce. Hate how some pork buns have thick sauces and loaded with fat..this place is not like that.
Glad to grow up eating BBQ pork buns from this neighborhood bakery.

Everyone in there super chill as well..and they close one day a week..I think its mondays...
author: Linda T.

description:
mmmmm... Char Siu Bao... delicious...

The egg tart is also very good...especially for the price.
author: Zoran L.

description:
After passing by this place, I would never want to go in. I had a reservation down the block and thought a bar had recently opened in the neighborhood. The smell of smoke was thick in the air and it was a rainy evening too. When I passed by this bakery, I was choking at all the smoke that was being blown from the smokers sitting out front. 

Inside I can see a group of old men just sitting there playing their Chinese chess and screaming at each other. 

Cigarette smoke and men cursing at each other..
author: M C.

description: This place has amazing reviews... but the BBQ pork buns weren't that good!!! What??? I know. How??? Maybe my expectations were too high but I'm still pretty disappointed... It was OK not great. I thought the ladies behind the counter were really nice and cute though :)
author: Crystal L.

description:
Two PM, the day is clear and cool
To be out at this hour, decent folk would tell me I'm a fool
But leaving Lung Fung Bakery feels like a sin
I want to run back to the store and have the pork bun 'til the sun comes up again

Have It changed my life?
I love the bbq-pork bun still and I always will

Four PM, the day is over soon
the bbq-pork bun, it shine like diamonds, it glow just like the stars in the store
And I know we make each other mad sometimes
But love is behind all of it, and we'll still be in love when pain subsides

Now I hope It has changed my life
I hope the bbq-pork bun can be forever with me

14 years and counting
The 14 best years of bbq-pork bun
But don't confuse our love with memories
You know the best is yet to come

Two PM, and I'm on my way home
I think of no thing but the bbq-pork bun
I sing my song for the bbq-pork bun and the pork bun alone

And I'm glad the bbq-pork bun changed my life
Now I love the bbq-pork bun still
And I love the bbq-pork bun still
And I love the bbq-pork bun still

The original song by The Avett Brothers - I Love You Still
OMFG, what a boring, creepy song!
I've never hear of it.
I found by an accident.
JesusChrist! Gimme a Break!
I almost vomit just listen to it in youtube.
Fxxx!

But, I still love the BBQ pork bun!
I haven't been here for a while, so I had to check it out.
I am so glad that nothing has changed.
I saw the same old lady in there.
Few old Chinese men were hanging out, talking, reading papers.
Every thing in here hasn't change that much.
A dollar Great pork bun.
I got 3.
I'm lovin' them.
Still.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I've been going here for 20 years and my family from Chicago has to order 3 dozen every time they come here to take home.  

However not anymore.  I think the business was sold sometime this past summer 2015.  My sister said the last 3 dozen I got for her didn't taste right.  I said it was probably just her because why would a new owner change a recipe that has proven successful.  

Well today I stopped by and picked up 2 BBQ pork buns and when I bit into it I thought "she's right, they taste different". 

The bread is too buttery and not sweet enough and the BBQ pork, not tangy enough.  

So this is why they are getting 2 stars from me.  

Need to find a new place.   Shame on the new owners for changing the recipe.
author: Peter W.

description:
When it comes to char siu bao there really isn't any place better.  Its definitely a hole in the wall and wouldn't think of stopping in to get anything. I got introduced to this place by a friend of my parents and been hooked from the start.

Its a very small place and can be pretty intimidating to the first timer because of the crowd that hangs out there ( loud old Chinese guys).  But don't let that stop you.  They just confirm that this is the spot to be.  

GET THE PORK BUNS!  They are top notch and very hard to find anything that's just like them.  The meat-to-bun ratio is just right and the mix of savory and sweet is great.  The other pastries there are good too but i go for the buns.  If you go know you're going to get a lot of them CALL IN ADVANCE.  So they can be sure to bake some for your order,  I went one time and wanted to get a bunch without calling first and i was saddened to only get the 4 that were left because they would have to cook more and i couldn't wait.

This has become a mandatory pit stop when I'm in the area.  I Love this place and you guys will too.
author: Roberto C.

description:
I was that geeky kid in elementary school, who was ALWAYS excited about school. Going to school in first or second grade meant a new game of kickball awaited me. Third grade was the chance to jump rope with the other early birds while fourth grad meant the opportunity to shut down some of the boys in a game of knockout. And fifth grade was all about going early to the library to solve Super Sleuth or Calendar Clue. 

However, to get me even more excited about going to school, my Dad use to take me to Lung Fung Bakery, the local chinese bakery to get a hot dog bun for breakfast and then walk me to my elementary school. One of the coolest father-daughter bonding moments of my childhood. 

As I got older, my auntie would take me afterschool to get the char siu baos or the pineapple buns or the red bean buns or multiple buns if I couldn't make up my mind.

Today, some 15+ years later, they still make amazing char siu baos. They're not stingy on the meat and one bite is just pure deliciousness. Going here means stop caring about where all those calories are going and just inhale.

YUM.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
I come here for 2 things -- the egg tarts and the baked char siu bao.  Both are excellent and one of the best around when fresh out of the oven, and even if they've been sitting around its still pretty damn good.  They appear to bake all day long.  Better than Golden Gate Bakery imo.  

I sometimes will also get one of those huge almond cookies, which is super flaky and a little too buttery, but pretty solid.

Plus the lady is always friendly (I speak Cantonese to her), and there is never a wait.  Easy in, easy out, I'm never in the place for more than 5 minutes.  

For someone visiting this place for the first time, it might be a bit loud and intimidating if you go there in the afternoon...just ignore all those old Chinese men playing checkers and talking loudly...it's their hangout I suppose.
author: j k.

description:
I came here because I needed a quick lunch and it was way too hard to find parking near Clement and 10th-ish.  I drove right up to Lung Fung Bakery (plenty of metered parking right in front), put a nickel in the meter, ordered/received my food and was off in less than a couple of minutes.  

The woman behind the counter was very friendly and cheerful.  She pretty much read my mind and said "don't worry, we have fresh egg tarts just out of the oven" before I even ordered any egg tarts.  I was impressed.  I asked for 3 egg tarts and she brought them out on a pan, so that I could take a look at them.  They looked delicious- so she bagged them up for me.  I also ordered one bbq pork bun.  The total for the four items was $3 even- which seems like a very fair price.  

The pork bun was large and very filling.  It wasn't overly bread-y and the flling was meaty.  It wasn't too sauce-y and didn't have a lot of fatty pieces, which I liked.  It wasn't the best pork bun that I've had, but it was good.

The egg tarts were great.  Few things can top a warm egg tart, fresh out of the oven.  They filling was soft and custardy, and the crust was flakey.  Very good, and quite a deal at just $0.70 each.  I'd recommend Lung Fung.
author: Samantha L.

description:
A haiku for you:

B-B-Q pork bun
Get them here, it is awesome
Egg tart is great too
author: Eric C.

description: As a native San Franciscan Chinese American who grew up in North Beach / Chinatown and has eaten plenty of cha sell bao (BBQ pork buns), this is the best I've had. Why: no fat globs or questionable meat inside, not too sweet, high filling to bread ratio, tasty filling almost like it has liquor in it, bread is thin and has a crisp surface, hefty size. And I love that I can speak Hoisanwa to the lady who works there and always smiles :) She's very nice. These buns are $1.10/piece. Ahn tot (custard tarts) are also delicious.
author: Kimberly D.

description:
Like children under the age of five, nacho cheese's arrival to any refreshment table, and Chris Brown to ignorant teenage girls, Lung Fung Bakery can commit no wrong.  

Perhaps my judgement is skewed due to unwavering loyalty to my provider of fresh Chinese pastries since infancy, but Lung Fung's commitment to excellency abounds in its goods.  The pineapple bun's (bo lo bao) soft, doughy texture and gently crunchy sugar topping, cocktail bun's (gai mei bao) abundantly rich, silky custard, and egg tart's (dan tat) light, flaky crust are testaments of the baker's expertise.

The enthused chatter of Chinese grandpas shuffling through newspapers and gathering around games of chess creates the atmosphere of a Chinatown transplant that only reinforces the legitimacy of Lung Fung Bakery for all your Chinese pastry needs.
author: Andrew M.

description:
These are as legit as a Chinese BBQ pork bun gets. They are served warm, and the oogey gooey BBQ porkness just melts in your mouth..just for a single dollar.

Don't be let the pigeon roaming around the store throw you off. This is a must if you're cruising around the Outer Richmond. And they're old school Chinese peeps.. so make sure you come handy with the green paper!
author: Crystal C.

description: After searching for a bbq bun place thats not in the hustle and bustle of Chinatown I found this place after being a bit disappointed by Victors bakery in the sunset area. This place is awesome. Nice lady behind the counter kept asking me if I wanted egg tarts since she just pulled them out of the oven, I declined since I don't like egg tarts. I came for the bbq bun and the bbq buns only. Soft bread but with a nice crust on top and their bread to bbq ratio was spot on. Yummy I guess I found my go to bun place.
author: Julie C.

description:
This place makes good custard, no lines like GG in Chinatown.  Easy parking.  But, 

1) I cannot stand those old Chinese men playing chess and using foul language.  I mean they curse like there's no tomorrow.  Parents, don't bring your kids into the store, if they understand Cantonese.

2) The lady owner is really nice, but using the same hand to collect money and grabbing your bao is not acceptable.
author: SF F.

description: Yummy pineapple buns and okay hotdog buns! I wish I tried the bbq pork everyone's talking about in their reviews :( I stumbled upon this place after my facial and didn't read the yelp reviews until after I left because I was too hungry :( oh well there's always next time! Will be back
author: Michelle H.

description: Amazingly good pork buns. Very nice people work there.
author: Laura S.

description: The bakery is under new ownership.  The nice lady who has worked/owned the place retired.  I really miss her smile & greeting!  Got my usual pork buns & was disappointed.  The pork filling was too sweet & the pork was chopped unevenly.  Some large pieces & fatty tendon included. The lady behind the counter gave me the wrong change.  I gave her a $20 & got change for a $10.  She very promptly gave me a 10 back when I told her.  Watch your change. Not sure if I'll go back.  Very disappointed as I have been going there for 10-15 years.
author: Diner D.

description: Y'all need to get on that Bbq Pork buns hype! Only a buck for one. I loaded up on a few and the egg tarts are pretty good too. Don't wait till the end of the day as they sometimes run out. But that's just a sign of how good they are. You won't regret it!
author: Phil D.

description:
At first I was going to put 4 stars, but after a few more trips here I'm sold.  Bakery from the outside doesn't look inviting (kind of dirty from the outside, bunch of old Chinese men playing mahjong on the inside and don't really care to move out of your way when you go in), but this place is fantastic.

Highly suggest going between late AM and early PM.  That's when things are the most fresh.  I would say their top things are (1) BBQ Pork buns, (2) Cocktail buns, and (3) Egg tarts.

The BBQ pork buns aren't the biggest you'll find, but the bread is baked with perfect balance of browned and soft.  It's got a nice crust on the outside top and really soft and chewy as you get towards the BBQ pork.  The BBQ pork is fresh and very tasty.

Cocktail buns - again not the biggest you'll find but the coconut they use is very fresh.  It stands out and is delightfully tasty when you bite into the bun.  Always fresh bread too with a nice milky sweet taste.

Egg tarts - very fresh and the egg tart doesn't come apart.

Prices are very reasonable.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Went in last Friday morning to see what the rave was about. The baked pork buns are definitely different than many places and was pretty good as well as the egg tarts that were suggested. And the service was friendly so why only 3 stars? Well, IMHO, there are slight improvements that are needed for 4 to 5 stars but I believe it is a 3+ star experience.
The breakdown:
Baked pork buns were fluffy and not sticky due to the egg wash and not sugar glaze. And the pork was sliced in strips as opposed to cubits (which was traditionally done from left over BBQ pork) and there were no onions. Hence it was less sweet and a bit more salty. So this was a matter of preference.
The egg tart was a bit better than many in Chinatown but still has some qualities that, IMHO, trails Golden Gate Bakery. They layers are not as well defined but it seems the method is more complex than a faux puff paste. And the egg custard was not as loose/creamy.
Why wait in line or risk having to go to Golden Gate only to find that it is closed, when you can go here. This place has potential to meet or pass what is considered the best Chinese bakery in the city.
author: H C.

description: This is one of my favorite places to eat in sf. The pork buns are the best I've had anywhere. The lady behind the counter was nice and suggested a few new things to try. I had something that tasted like it had curry in it that was absolutely incredible, even after being reheated the next day. Can't wait to go back!
author: Emily K.

description:
Oh Lung Fung Bakery, you always have and always will have a special place in my heart. Your pork buns, cocktail buns, and egg tarts are truly God's way of saying "it's okay to be a fat ass, as long as the food you're stuffing down your face tastes good". 

I've grown up with this place since I was in elementary school and it wasn't until recently that I realized how good I've had it with chinese pastries (because of Lung Fung). Long story short, I was hungry one day. Lung Fung wasn't anywhere nearby so i decided to find the nearest chinese bakery by me. Upon arrival, I ordered a pork bun. To my great surprise, that shit sucked. And with that, I apologize Lung Fung. I'm a filthy, dirty cheater and I have thoroughly learned my lesson.

Oh and also, the people here are super sweet and friendly. I always make sure to tip the lady every time I come and while I succeed in doing so, she and I always run into a "tipping tango"  around the tip jar where she tries to push my hand away. This only makes me want to give her more!!! On top of that, she's always giving me extra buns for no reason. People like her remind me that warm and generous people still do exist in the world. :)

Lung Fung Bakery, all day err day.
author: Marilyn L.

description: Small mom n pop place that offers airy egg tart.
author: Diesel M.

description: Went here twice, on a Saturday afternoon and Sunday morning. Wasn't open either time. Don't know how this place can get so many good reviews when it isn't open on the weekends. Not sure if this weekend was special because there wasn't a notice posted on the door. Not worth the bus fare to go out there.
author: Thomas J.

description:
We stopped here since we were waiting for our table at Hong Kong Lounge. So what better than some pork buns while you're waiting to eat dim sum. They're warm, delicious and cheap. 

Highly recommend walking over if you're in the  neighborhood
author: Komal B.

description:
Happiness is...

...waking up early on a Saturday morning before the rest of the universe.

...crossing the bridge with no traffic.

...instantly finding parking in the Richmond.

...being warmly greeted by a smiling Chinese woman at the counter.

...facing a huge language barrier that somehow universal sign language seems to magically break down.

...refusing an amusing failed attempt at having some kind of mystery meat hot dog bun thingy-ma-jiggy pawned off on me.

...scoring the last two baked BBQ pork buns before 10:30 am.

...and enjoying every delicious pork-tastic bite with the 200 pennies that I found in between my sofa cushions.
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Seriously the best char siu bao (buns) I've ever had. Astonishing. Having lived in Hawaii where manapua (pork bao) is ubiquitous, I thought I'd tried them all. No way. Lung Fung makes a superb bao that exceeds any I've ever had. I know an older Chinese lady who lives in Chinatown but travels all the way (bus and cable car) to Clement Street for Lung Fung's bao. Because they are THAT delicious. 

The bakery itself is like travelling back in time to the forties. Totally unassuming, very uncorporate, and just a funky, place to be. No hipsters here. I love it. 

The Chinese sheet cakes are also very good. Imagine: two sponge cake layers with a real fruit middle, and topped with whipped cream, a bit of frosting, and lots of fruit ... strawberries, pineapple, etc. Very light and tasty. 

But the BAO. Delicious. It's a perfectly baked bun with pulled pork and gravy in the middle. For a $1 each, it's the best bargain I've found in SF. The custard tarts (70 cents) are also very tasty!
author: Melissa K.

description: Can't believe how cheap the pastries are here. Actually came here twice in one weekend. Quick breakfast. The curry pie tasted just like curry, but it's missing more of meat filling as compared to what I'm used to. The chicken pie, tasted and looked like an American chicken pot pie, I wish it were more Asian. Both were deliciously cheap, I'd come back.
author: Arnold W.

description:
Every time I stop by Lung Fung, I can't help but order out the whole bakery!   (Well almost hehe) 

Box full of :

8 Cha Siew Baos (BBQ Pork)
4 Gai Mei Baos (Cocktail Bun)
4 Green Onion Buns
3 Hot Dog Buns
4 Dan Tat (Egg Tart) 

Just got home, and devoured a Cha Siew Bao, Green Onion Bun, and Gai Mei Bao, all in one sitting.  It seems like no matter what time of day I go to Lung Fung, the buns are nice and juicy, and piping hot out of the oven--perfect, just the way I like'em.   Extremely pleased, never dissatisfied! 

Hands down, the best Chinese Bakery in my eyes!
author: Cass J.

description:
Wow, this little bakery is great!! A fellow yelper recommended this place, so while in San Fran today, I decided to swing by. 


It's pretty small, there's not a huge selection compared to most bakery's. 

There were pork buns, egg tarts, coconut tarts, red bean pastries, mini moon pies and a couple other items I can not recall. 

Parking was a cinch + 
Service was nice + from standing at the register you can take a glimpse in to the kitchen and see them making the pastry which is kind of cool. 

Got a few little treats- 

Egg tart - Delicious!! Beats Golden Gate Bakery by a land slide (To me) fully cooked- The texture was incredibly creamy, flavor was wonderful- crust was a buttery, crisp flaky perfection and did not fall all over the place!! 

Mini moon pie- Ok, not the best, outer shell not as golden and flaky as I like, yet tasty. 

I got one of the red bean pastries as well,I have not yet tried it though it looks and smells delicious. 

Extremely inexpensive and very delicious I will be back!!
author: Shannon H.

description: I gave a 5 stars for their egg tarts because it's the best egg tart in the bay. Although if it's in NYC, you can find this kind of quality egg tart anywhere, i would have given a 4 stars reviews in NYC.... but here, people don't know how to make egg tart, the flaky, not too sweet, juicy custard, only here you find it.
author: Ashley C.

description: Ran into this little place and it was packed with elder Chinese grandpa playing Chinese chess. It was so packed so I decided to yelp it and saw the high reviews. The fob in me couldn't resist a good egg tart and decide to try one and the verdict?!?! Great egg filling- milky and eggy but as for the crust... It's nothing special barely acceptable( well not acceptable in Hong Kong that's for sure).
author: jasmin t.

description: While waiting for a smog certificate, I finally dropped back in at LF to nosh on some char-siu baos. Solid eats that did not disappoint. The baos were biggie-size, and the filling had large cube-cuts of pork in a rich and savory/sweet thick "pork" sauce. I go half-a -dozen. Lotsa po po's and gong gong's chatting away in this bakery, so high-comedy awaits if you can understand the Cantonese. 4.5 rounding up to 5.0. fistpump!
author: Derek N.

description:
Good pork buns, but very rude owners, I had ordered 50 over the phone and I was told to come in an hour, when I showed up they would only give me 10 with no explanation, there were dozens more in the case.
Rude
author: Randy , Michio U.

description:
I showed up before closing, and they were mostly sold out.

So other than egg tart and BBQ Pork buns,  I also got some coconut tart and coconut bun.  They were ok, but I think will stick with the egg tart  and BBQ pork buns.

TIP: Preorder --The owner is super friendly, and told me I can pre-order next time so I will be sure to have the amount I want.
author: Coco L.

description: I only had two or three items but hands down the best pork buns in San Francisco. The price cannot be beat l...ady was really friendly
author: Jeremy R.

description: Dim sum, BBQ pork buns, or Manapua.  Whatever you call it, its the place to get it.  Delicious!
author: Janis G.

description:
FIVE STARS FOR PORK BUNS!

I've been eating pork buns all my life. American kids drink milk and eat PB&J, Chinese kids eat pork buns and drink Vita Soy. What?

As a kid growing up in the city, I rarely made my way this deep into the Richmond. It was all about the Sunset and Chinatown. Therefore, it was only recently that I discovered how God really makes pork buns. 

Every one I've had from here has been hot and loaded with pork filling. Even though other places are good, this place has a mega one up from the others because the pork buns always taste fresh and right out of the oven. 

Maybe I'm just lucky when it comes to getting pork buns from here, but I hope when you decide to mosey on over, you get lucky too.
author: NickJess S.

description:
What nice buns you have Lung Fung. Roaming aimlessly around Outer Richmond with my Yelp App in hand I did what any sensible person would do- I started searching for boba and Asian bakeries. There was simply no way I could pass up Lung Fung with its stellar shining stars!

When we pulled up out front, we were a bit intimidated by the tables of elderly Asian men gossiping, playing card games, and eyeing us on the curb. However, the large, easy to read sign announcing .70 baked buns beckoned loudly. Plus, the front window was plastered with "People Love Us On Yelp" stickers. I sent my husband inside. 

He returned with simple gatherings, a red bean bun and a pineapple red bean bun. He also reported that the lady inside was as sweet as the goods she was selling. What happened next is a little foggy, but it involved cramming pastries in our mouth and mumbling, "Oh my God..." repeatedly. The pineapple red bean bun was still warm and magically doughy, like the yummiest white bread I ate plain as a kid, but sweeter and filled with a warm, gooey red bean filling. The straight red bean had flaky layers, also delicious but upstaged by the freshness of the prior delight. 

These were definitely quality buns. Maybe just maybe they were not the absolute best I have ever had, but at .70, I could eat two or three just to double-check.
author: Misti Y.

description:
Took one of my cars out for a test drive before work after a make-shift repair yesterday morning and decided to surprise my co-workers.  Picked up two dozen baked BBQ pork buns, fresh out of the oven and wow, they were a total hit!

Everybody in the office loved them and just couldn't stop thanking me.  It even disrupted the morning meeting as people kept running out to get some as they came in and heard about them...those who didn't run out kept talking about how much they loved them during the meeting...it was hilarious!  

I couldn't believe how quickly it all disappeared...they went fast!!!  The lady working there is great too.  Definitely my favorite place in SF for BBQ pork buns.
author: Roy N.

description:
I basically grew up eating the baked goods from here! This is the coffee shop that my dad and uncles have always gone to ever since I could remember. This place is usually crowded with men in the morning before people start work. During the middle of the day, you can always see middle aged to more elderly men playing Chinese chess here. It's not some place I'd personally sit down at, but I always enjoy eating their buns. It's just a nice neighborhood spot even though it doesn't look too appealing on the outside. 

Throughout the years, I've gone through different phases of what kind of buns I liked eating from here but I've never been disappointed. I also like the spongecakes and egg tarts too. 

The staff here is so friendly. I remember my dad bringing me here sometimes before school to buy some breakfast or sometimes cake for our birthdays. The owners are always laughing and smiling no matter what. 

They have good Asian style cakes but I just prefer my tiramisu now so I've stopped coming here for that but I always appreciate one of the Chinese buns when I'm in a rush. The price is right! It's just so cheap and good.
author: Connie Y.

description: Great bakery! I've been coming here for over 20 years! My favorite item to order is their char sui bao. Mmmmmm I usually order it in large quantities because I usually share them with my friends and family! If you are a vegetarian I recommend their cocktail buns! They're sweet and good tasting! I've never had anything that I didn't like here! Also their prices are very reasonable too!!!
author: Sayuri I.

description: I have been going there for over 20 plus years,I live in Palo Alto, I buy any where from six dozen to 14 dozen baked pork buns,to take home to share and freeze.  Reminds me of fresh Hawain bread with great lean marinated pork meat.  Try it you will be back.  Great Don Tot  baked  Custrad Tart,best just out of the oven or reheat 15 seconds. Also great paper chiffon cake.  Been run buy husband the baker and wife,2 person operation,  Mom & Pop  The children use to help,but now have left the nest.  Tell her Mr. Leung from Palo Alto sent you.
author: RONALD L.

description: Great bakery with perfectly flakey custard tarts. It's always full of old men playing with their Chinese chess.
author: Patrick L.

description: The hot dog and pork buns great!!! The lady behind the counter is very friendly. This place is perfect.
author: James M.

description: pineapple buns ran out before noon. like how are you supposed to run a business if you don't even know to properly manage your bread inventory? sheesh..
author: Betty T.

description:
"Pork buns are a hell of a drug."  

Awesome little spot, which I guess has been around according to the other reviews by neighborhood folks. 

The lady at the counter is super friendly, always has a smile and delicious baked good waiting when you walk in. At this point she recognizes me as a regular customer, the small talk has increased with each visit.

I don't know what they put in those things (pork buns) but damn I keep going back. Best $1 I have ever spent. The items there are very fairly priced, I would even say very cheap for what other bakeries charge. 

I've been so stuck on the pork buns I haven't even tried the deserts, I'm going to read  over the reviews below and try something new today!
author: Richie C.

description: Their egg custard is very good and fresh!! And the lady (the owner) very friendly and always have a nice smile, so I like go there all the time!
author: Emily W.

description: My sweet buttercream bun! I was introduced to these buns over 2 years ago. They have an amazing creamy sweet conconutty taste and are the best when you microwave them for about 15-25 seconds. Don't over heat it because it will turn into a rock. I was in sf for the wkend and we stopped by LF bakery. We ordered 2 dozen coconut buttercream buns to take home at .70 cents a piece. Great deal! I also got an egg tart 4/5, coconut pastry thing 4/5 and a bbq pork bun for bf's bro (he says it was real good). I can't find the coconut buns anywhere else. My mom has looked all over OC for them. We waited about 10 mins for a fresh batch to come out of the oven, but otherwise their service is pretty good. There are a whole bunch of old china men who sit around and play Chinese chess all day inside the bakery.
author: Kim l.

description: Don't be afraid to try the other stuff on the menu. The Hot Dog bun and Cocktail bun are both very good - the Cocktail bun is almost the same (but not as buttery or coconutty) as the coconut thing they have at King Bakery on Mission. The Ham and Egg bun is gross, mainly because of the undercooked eggs. But if you like moist scrambled egg, the rest of the bun is good.
author: Joe G.

description: This place has my favorite Baked BBQ Pork Buns of all time!!  It's so soft and the texture of the bun is more moist than most other places (which can be a little dry at times).  I grew up in this neighborhood and remember my mom taking me here on occasion to get either a birthday cake or an assortment of buns to bring home.  Their cocktail buns,  pineapple buns, chicken pies, curry beef pies, and hotdog buns are all delicious as well.  There's a really sweet lady at the counter who encourages you to by more stuff to fill the bag or pink pastry box...and sometimes you can't help but to say yes.
author: Alvin J.

description:
One of the best place in town to get those bbq pork buns!!!  My grandma lives in this neighborhood and so happen to stop by to pick up a dozen of those buns a few years ago.  She offered us some and I've been stopping by Lung Fung each and everytime I visit my grandparents. 

But why do I always get the lady that only speaks chinese.  With my broken up chinese, I'm surprised that she actually understands me!  She gets 5 stars for that :-)

The pork buns here just right, they don't have that fatty meat in it like a lot of the other places do.

I've also have tried their egg custards, they are pretty darn good.  Their red bean pineapple buns are awesome as well.  Their cocktail buns aren't bad either.  If you look in their show case, they have this sponge cake that looks kind of like a cone, that's pretty good too.  It kind taste like angel food cake.

Lung Fung, you'll always get my business.
author: Shana W.

description:
When I was younger, my grandma bought me to this bakery every day for breakfast. I fell in love with the cha sui bao since day 1. I haven't been to this bakery in over 5 years, and one day my friend and I came up on a topic of Chinese buns, immediately the first thing that popped up in my mind was the cha sui bao in Lung Fung's bakery. So I forced him to go, and it was still the little shop I remembered with the same bao I loved so much. I always looked forward to sinking my teeth into the warm, sweet, crispy bun. Within the bun is the hot, juicy barbecued pork that just fills my mouth with glee as I go in for a second bite. Simply amazing. I can't say anymore or else I'll burst into tears talking about how wonderful the taste is. 
This little bakery sells its buns at a cheap price ($0.50 - $1.00 a bun, what a steal!) so I can always get a bun even if I'm low on cash! I highly recommend stopping by, and trying anything out on their menu!
author: Anthony H.

description:
This place has probably the 2nd best egg tarts compared to golden gate in Chinatown and for half the price!!! Sure, the flavor of the eggs is not as rich, but it is half the price!! They do master the flakey crust,which makes it a winner in my book!! 

They also have amazinggg BBQ pork buns, pineapple buns, and my favorite raisin bread!!  Whenever I'm in the Richmond area, I always like to come here to buy my breads!  They're cheaper than a lot of other places and much fresher!

The sad part is that you have to rely on luck to see what is still in stock, because of a lot of breads get sold out and you will have to wait for the next batch to come out of the kitchen.
author: stephanie c.

description: Found this bakery on Yelp. Went in January, but they were closed. Before I went March, I called first. Ordered piping hot baked  BBQ pork buns, which were excellent. Big sized buns for only $1.10 each. And got egg custard tarts. These are soooo good and only 80 cents each. The couple running the bakery are so cute!
author: Roz T.

description:
As I was driving through Richmond to get to the Presidio, I recalled a friend saying they made a pretty good egg tart here (though he qualified it, saying it couldn't beat the one at Golden Gate). So, I made the slightest of detours. Unfortunately, when I arrived they were all out despite it being only noon with no customers in the shop.

I settled for a couple baked charsiu bao -- BBQ pork buns. Were they good? I liked the texture and taste of the bread, and that it didn't have paper on the bottom (which when removed often fails to detach completely, or else takes some of the bread with it causing your filling to fall out the bottom). I didn't like that the top had been brushed with oil where other shops have a light honey glaze. They could've forgone the shine or used an egg wash if they didn't want it sugary. The pork in the filling was OK. But, the sauce was too thick and there was too much of it.

I didn't experience the awesomeness that others are yelping about. It was... above average.

I'm still curious about the egg tarts. But, it'll have to wait, as I won't be going out of my way to try them.
author: Leo G.

description:
Oh my my! 
How can you resist the sweet smell of fresh Cha siew bao! (Pork Bun)

My mother brought these home one day and I couldn't let them go.
I could swear they put crack in their food. I CRAVE it. 
First bite into the bao and you already hit the meat?! That's basically unheard of! Throughout the whole thing you get the meat and the bun which is evenly proportioned. You get the fatty-ness from the pork and the carbs from the bun and the sweetness. It's like an orgasm happened in your mouth.

I've had a few other things here and I will say they are good, but you HAVE to try the cha siew bao. I've never been so amazed in my life.
author: Stephanie M.

description: The best place to get your simple Chinese bakery,
author: Seaera T.

description: Right next to golden gate dim sum (http://www.yelp.com/biz/golden-gate-dim-sum-seafood-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:XDFwtDeziJSA3XELJg9S0Q) this place offers fresh chinese baked goods at reasonable prices. Its the usual stop after a nice dim sum lunch as its quite convenient.
author: Robert Y.

description:
So I am mixed about this place, hence the 3 stars.

The good? their cakes are delicious, not too sweet - just the way I like. the pork buns? The outside of the bun is crisp and a delight, the pork however is a bit too salty for my taste. The price? Unbeatable, five bucks spent here could fill me up the whole day.

The mediocre? Flavor wise, their egg tarts can't compare to Golden Gate, I'd only buy them from here if I didn't want to travel to China Town. Also, they host chinese checkers or something daily and most of these men smoke, so it really deters me from coming in sometimes.
author: Care T.

description:
the bbq pork is really good just like everyone says.
the lady there is super nice.
its also really easy to get it because we are always in/out in notime since there is almost never a wait when we have gone there on the weekends.
author: Alex H.

description:
BBQ pork bun - good at 90-cents.  Pineapple bun and Cocktail bun - good at 50-cents.  I love this place because it's walking distance to the bus stop, but I wouldn't "travel" here for the buns.  Almost everything is good here, esp. for the price and the wonderful service.

If you're in the hood - come & get some buns!
author: Bessie T.

description:
I had a hankering for a BBQ pork bun the other day, and remembered I'd been in Lung Fung every now and then for an egg tart, so I figured I'd give the buns a try.   

The workers are very friendly and eager to help anyone who wanders in, and once you get past the lively group of regulars, any intimidation you might feel quickly slips away and likely won't happen at all if you go there often enough.

And the reviews singing the praises of the pork bun?  No kidding, these things are awesome!
