Granted, I'm more of a steamed bun kind of girl and these are baked, but they're hot, they're delicious, and get this...no, seriously...NO MSG!!!  In a BBQ pork bun!  Really!  Okay, it's possible there's a teeny tiny bit, but as someone who is very sensitive to the stuff and gets the headaches and the digestive issues shortly after consuming it (the more there is, the worse it gets), I can honestly say I couldn't tell, which means there was barely a trace, if that.  Considering that I tend to notice a high concentration of MSG in most Chinese BBQ pork dishes, it's really nice to be able to consume these with wild abandon.  

So, no MSG, great workers and I can be stuffed for well under $5 (with leftovers) - it doesn't make sense to give this spot less than 5 stars.
author: Sus... B.

description: Discovered this spot when I was at Hong Kong bakery and was told that it would be an additional 20 minutes for dessert (should have ordered them ahead of time with the rest of the dim sum).  Yelped and found Lung Fung Bakery nearby, and I'm so glad I did!  Truly delicious, warm pineapple buns and egg tarts at a great price.  What more can you ask for?
author: Lily L.

description:
My girlfriend and I was on our way to check out the Fairy Lake Aquarium when we came across this little bakery.  We each had an egg custard tart (which just came out of the oven) and a BBQ bun, both of which were...... Mutha Fockin' Good!!!
I've had lots of BBQ bun before, but these were absolutely ambrosial!  The bun itself was soft and moist, while the BBQ pork was well flavored and easy to chew. 
So if you got the munchies, I would highly recommend dropping by this place to grab a BBQ bun or two (I would get two cuz if your girlfriend is remotely like mine, then you wouldn't even get a chance to eat your entire bun... cuz she would eat mine...and that's how she roll).
author: Patrick L.

description:
Well, I am not a fan of the BBQ pork bun, but that's not Lung Fung's fault. But their dan tat and red bean buns are awesome!

Not a day goes by that I don't think of getting one, but my waist line is thankful I skip a few days, I guess. To compare it to Golden Gate Bakery in Chinatown, I can't say one is better than the other. Always fresh at both, but only LF is across the street.

-1 star because they are almost always out of red bean buns. They're that good. Nice eggy, crumbly pineapple top (shape/pattern not fruit, of course) above a soft bun filled with sweet adzuki. Mmm.

All the chess players look at me odd when I walk in, but then they go right back to their game. They're boggling to watch, I don't know why.

Oh, I saw styrofoam, but only a little, as if they were trying to get rid of it. There is also paper cups for the coffee.
author: Willy R.

description:
my quest to find a baked bbq pork bun that trumps Great Eastern Restaurant in Chinatown brought me to Richmond, specifically here to Lung Fung's.

the egg tarts ($.70) are light and creamy, better than some of the bakeries in chinatown. the pork bun ($1) was ok, bland for my taste--i wanted more flavor in the bbq pork. but their bread is amazing. so all their buns, as far as the bread goes, are great.

their pineapple bun is out of this world. insane. $.50! it was doughy and soft in the center with a top crunchy layer that complimented the soft warm dough so well. delightful. i would have given them 3 stars, but the pineapple bun deserved an extra star.
author: Melissa N.

description: PORK BUN heaven!!!  Coconut Cream something, off tha HOOK delish!!
author: Krista H.

description:
I might be a bit weird in the sense that most Chinese baked goodies don't appeal to me much, with BBQ pork buns being the lone exception. I usually go to Cafe Bakery and get theirs, but I thought I'd try Lung Fung for a change.

Pound for pound, it's pretty close to the legendary buns from CB, but two things bring them down:

1) The buns just don't taste as sweet. And they are flat in comparison. Like when you unknowingly sit on a sandwich kind of flat. This can be avoided if you eat it on the spot, but I usually have them pack a dozen up to go, and by the time I get home, they're mashed.

2) The BBQ pork isn't quite as fatty. And it needs to be, for real. I've come to the conclusion that the awesomeness of a BBQ pork bun is directly proportional to the amount of fatty pork inside. Less fattiness, less awesomeness.

Basically, they're still a good bun, but you can get better at Cafe Bakery.
author: David H.

description: A coworker recommended this place to me.  Past the old men playing cards are the best baked pork buns in the bay area. They have the perfect balance of pork and bun.
author: Roy T.

description: The pork buns, pineapple buns, egg tarts, etc are all good here!! And.. it's a great bargain!
author: Mertani G.

description:
I love that the buns are always kept warm. Whatever time of day you drop in, you'll be present with hot buns. The bread is of perfect texture and sweetness. Of course, the one thing to order is the pork bun. Every single person I have taken here has been impressed. Last week, I had my friend drive us here. We bought three pork buns and headed towards the beach. After he finished eating those, he declared, "We're going back to that bakery." And so we did, where he proceeded to load up on the goods--some to devour then and there, others to bring home. 

Other items are also delicious and inexpensive. I'd prefer if the pineapple buns were rounder and fluffier like this other place on Clement closer to inner Richmond. (I can't quite remember the name, so to avoid misleading anyone I'll withhold on specifics for now.) Lung Fung's pineapple bun topping is...well, soggy, while I prefer it at least semi-crunchy. That doesn't deter me from buying those with red bean or custard filling, though. 
However, pork buns here can't be beat. I love how there seems to be less fat contained in these than the typical pork filling. 

The woman who runs the store front is very sweet and always has a smile on her face. =)
author: Liana L.

description:
Oooh, my tummy is full from eating too many Chinese buns.  Lung Fung has a smaller selection including cookies, cream horns, egg tarts, sponge cupcakes (paper wrapped cakes), and always warm baked buns.  Warm buns are much better than cold buns.  Unlike most places, their buns aren't round.

Prices are cheap (70-90 cents per bun)!  The menu is in English too.  

I didn't plan on buying a BBQ pork bun but the lady who helped me asked me if I wanted one - so maybe she thinks they have excellent BBQ pork buns?  The BBQ pork bun turned out to be my favorite though red bean buns are usually my favorite.

* BBQ pork bun (90 cents): Soft, warm dough surrounds a generous amount of savory pork filling and a thick, slightly sweet brown sauce.  It's nice that they don't add fillers like onions and they use decent meat that doesn't look weird and red.
* Paper wrapped cakes: Light, not too sweet but lacking in flavor
* Egg tarts: Shell isn't as flaky as I like, filling is a little lacking in flavor, doesn't come close to Golden Gate Bakery or even Sheng Kee
* Ham and egg bun: The egg was very tender, came with a strip of ham, chewy wheat bun.  The bun should be softer ideally.
* Red bean pineapple bun (70 cents): I'm disappointed they didn't have plain red bean buns.  The red bean filling was very good (strong red bean flavor) but the bun was tougher/harder than I prefer.  The pineapple topping wasn't as thick, flaky or sweet as other places - which is fine by me since I'm not a fan of pineapple topping.  My favorite red bean buns in SF are at Sweet Passion Bakery on Taraval (and they're always warm).

The bakery looks pretty old and has some seating.  It's definitely no frills.  I like how the kitchen is visible so you can see them making buns.   

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
From my house, there are about 10 different Chinese bakeries that I could walk to for a pork bun... Lung Fung Bakery is not one of them!

So why do I go out of my way... hop in the car... race over to Lung Fung early in the morning? Because that's how great there pork buns are!!!! One bite into the soft bun leads you into a mouth savoring center of bbq pork. It will give you instant gratification!

I've always been a great supporter of family owned businesses, it keeps the money in the local economy and the quality is usually much better! The owner and his family are extremely nice! Always very friendly and attentive! 

Every time I go there I must get a dozen of them at the minimum... why? because they are so good that you want more than one! and being the person I am, I also share with my friends and co-workers!!!
author: David H.

description:
Oh me, oh my... some days it's pretty hard to get out of bed without some char siu bao. I usually keep a few in a shoebox on my nightstand, or at least under my pillow sans the box. But all these pillows of gastronomic furor are not created equally. 

Lung Fung. Oh, Lung Fung. I love your bao like my friend looks like Chairman Mao, and he's a dead ringer.
author: Roy M.

description: Whenever I'm in the city, I always make an obligatory stop here to stock up on BBQ pork buns and treat myself to a few egg tarts.  Both items are INCREDIBLY DELISH and a STEAL -- their BBQ pork bun blows Golden Gate Bakery out of the water, and I actually was never a fan of egg tarts until I tried them here.  Most everything on their menu is $1 or less (despite the fact that prices seem to steadily increase with each visit).  And the people who work here are always smiling and willing to strike up a deal.  They often throw in extra goodies on the house, too -- but maybe it's just because by now they've recognized me as That Girl who always comes in asking for 20 BBQ pork buns at a time.
author: Alice C.

description:
Lung Fung has been around for a lonnnnnnng time- I remember coming here when I was in elementary school 13+ years ago. There are a few tables inside which are usually taken by the older folks who come here to play chinese checkers.

We drove past today and bought some eggtarts- they were warm and delicious! The owner was super nice- makes me want to just give her a hug!
author: M W.

description:
I've been coming here for 4 years and I haven't written a review, so if I want to get a shout out for cracking my first 100 reviews, I better get moving! so here goes:

Reasons for coming here vs the other 30+ Chinese bakeries on Clement Street:

1) Got a sweet tooth, but don't want something achingly sweet?  Go for the coconut butter cream buns- Just the right amout of sweetness to keep you coming back for more, but with a bit of buttery goodness.
to take the edge of the sugar.

2) Paper wrapped cake. Yum.   Doughy and soft and pillowy.

3)Red bean and pineapple bun.  Great breakfasty or snack item.

Forget Krispy Kremes and Danishes (Danishii?) I'm bringing these buns to my next morning meeting
author: Smruti S.

description:
It's weird that I never noticed this place before. Upon arrival, I saw a crowd of elderly Chinese men playing Chinese chess. It was a touching sight....who doesn't have a soft spot for old people? Anyways, I came here for the sole purpose of eating egg tarts (dan tat) because I found out that Golden Gate Bakery was on vacation AGAIN!! Unbelievable...

I am not going to say that this is THE best egg tart I have ever had...that honor still goes to Golden Gate Bakery. But for 70 cents and for not having to dodge all the Chinese ladies with my car in Chinatown, I wouldn't mind having the egg tarts here as an alternative every now and then. The thing is, you need to bring these home and put it in your oven so you can have it warm and flaky. If you buy it at the store and eat it right away, there is a good chance you are eating a batch that is not fresh out of the oven and that does not do it justice. So, do yourself a favor and warm it up in a toaster oven at home and you'll see why some people would compare it to Golden Gate Bakery. But even after eating it warm out of my oven, the taste was a little bland. Nonetheless, I ate like 3 of them and I was satisfied. 

Also, the lady there claimed that their BBQ Pork buns were REALLY good...so I gave in and purchased one. It's not so good that I would drive from the Sunset to the Richmond to get it...but it WAS good! But, I live by Donut Time on Noriega street and the BBQ Pork bun is plenty good to me.
author: Allan M.

description:
There's one thing I have to do before I get into talking about the food. Can we just, for a few seconds, take our hats off in applause for the owner behind the counter at Lung Fung? If ever NASA were in need of a human calculator, she would be their go-to-guy. Forget about those silly 19th century cash registers. She blows them out of the water, the way she pushes the coins (which always rest on top of the counter) back to you for change even before you give her your payment. Man...and I thought the abacus was cool. 

Ok, onto the buns. While I don't really care for their egg custard tarts, I have to say that the rest of the buns Lung Fung makes are quite up to par. First off, the cocktail bun is good when it's warm. The coconut filling inside doesn't overpower the freshbaked aroma when it's consumed warm. Next, their BBQ pork buns are ok too. While I could do with a tad more filling, sometimes, nothing quite hits the spot like a nice, warm BBQ pork bun, with a slightly crispy top. Finally, the pineapple bun, which deserves its own paragraph.

I used to think that Alex Bakery made the best p-buns because I liked their crust the most. That was until I decided that the freshbaked buns from Lung Fung outclass Alex in both departments of crusty perfection and bunny excellence. I like to rip my buns apart as I eat them. In fact, it's sorta like my own inspection test. While the day old buns from Lung Fung flunk like no other, their freshbaked ones are head of the class -- in terms of aroma and softness. But the real taste of perfection lies in the crust. The way it's lain on top of the bun and hangs over the sides in little stalagmites of crusty heaven bring a tear to my eye and a drip to my lip. Amazing. (disclaimer: I'm only talking about the freshbaked ones.)

One more thing, I've always been intrigued by the Chinese chess playing that goes on here. You'd think that these gentlemen would play in the park, but their consistency says a lot for Lung Fung and its service to the community. As they can play chess and drink coffee all day, I can watch them and eat p-bun all day. Nice.
author: Philip W.

description:
The nicest owner in the whole world!  

They have the best bbq pork bun in the whole wide world. So juicy and savory and lean, no fatty meat like you'll find in other bbq pork buns.  It's a perfect breakfast!
author: Lily L.

description:
Best pork buns i have had as of yet in the city...
Almost like those of NYC's  Chinatown...

People are super super nice...Also mega games of chinese chess.
author: M.P R.

description: Cute neighborhood bakery where all the older Asian locals hang out.  I made a quick stop here at 8:30am to pick up some pineapple buns and egg tarts, which were fresh out of the oven! A big plus if you come early enough.  Otherwise, they run out of the popular pastries as the day progresses.  Minus one star for not having the little surprise center of the pineapple buns...that is the best part.  I loved the crisp top outer layer though.  This place is a smaller bakery so the selection isn't too big.
author: Lisa C.

description: Love their BBQ pork buns!  Only thing I ever tried from this bakery but it is darn good!  The bread is fluffy and light...not like some other places where it is thick and heavy.  The BBQ pork is seasoned prefectly...not too salty at all.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Let me just say this first. The Egg Tarts here can not compete with Golden Gate in Chinatown. The Filling here is okay, but the crust is dry.

BBQ Pork Buns and Chicken pies are pretty good, but the curry pies are really bad. 

Overall not too bad, agan Golden Gate wins hands down.
author: Vincent L.

description: Best Buns in SF, hands down. All of them are good. My favorites, Pineapple. Pineapple Custard, Pineapple Red Bean, Cocktail and Pork Bun. All outstanding. Lucky they are just a couple blocks away as well. Funny I never bought bun's anywhere but China Town, and these guys are right out the door!
author: Jordan P.

description:
I had to get something to eat, starving myself was not an option even after having my dang braces tightened T__T.  Lung Fung Bakery had quite a variety of buns, but my eyes just zoomed in on their offering of coconut cupcakes (60cents)! OMG, not many bakeries still bake these goodies, it's soo good! I got their cooked bbq pork bun (80 cents). The shiny top braised bun is crispy! Unlike many buns in the city that is soft, I wasn't expecting that new texture. The filling was good and hot.

Other than wading through the sea of old timers who gather to have their afternoon coffee, the place was pretty friendly and the smell heavenly.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Around the way from the crib. They have yummy pork buns and delicious curry puffs. You'll find a bunch of old chinese grandpas playing chinese chess or checkers. Its a whole in the wall place but the home made goods are worth my walk up the block.

For those that don't know a pork bun is BBQ pork stuffed a slightly sweet bun...sweet baked goodness.
author: Jody C.

description: Based on all those great Yelp reviews, I dropped by here to buy some buns.  Got some dinner rolls, onion rolls and pork buns.  The buns are ok.  They are a bit more expensive than the other bakeries in Clement.
author: Wendy H.

description: So this was the first baked BBQ pork bun that I've tried since moving to SF, and I have to say that they were pretty tasty.  At $0.90 a piece, the pork buns were delicious and steaming hot (unlike some dim sum places that serve them lukewarm).  The bun part was sweet and chewy, not at all dry, and the meat was flavorful, just a bit fatty (like most pork buns are).  Even my husband thought that the pork buns were really yummy, and he's usually leery of trying any kind of Chinese-hole-in-the-wall food product.  I'm hopeful that introducing him to more places like this will change his perceptions.
author: Ailene M.

description:
The egg tarts here are just as good as the ones from that one bakery on Stockton in Chinatown that eevveerrryoonne lines up for. Luckily, this quiet and friendly shop never has a line but still bake theirs fresh daily. The tarts usually gets out of the oven in the morning around 10? You'll find the regulars there daily shootin' the sheits and reading the Chinese newspaper. 

If you don't have enough change the owner lady doesn't mind, just make sure you'll pay her a visit again.
author: Faffy L.

description:
This is the place for pork buns.  Get there earlier than later because they go quick through the day.

Their sweet buns and ham and cheese buns are great too.
author: Patrick A.

description:
Awwwwww the pork bun. 

For some reason, I get always lucky: the store always has just put out freshly baked pork buns as I arrive. I stopped by the bakery again today, got one each for me and my boyfriend .. and couldn't resist but eat mine on the way home. And I almost got this impulse to lie to my boyfriend that they ran out of the pork buns so I could eat the other one too ....... ; ) 

I love the cocktail bun too. Quick service.
author: Joowon A.

description: I'm not a Hugh fan of pork buns(char sui bao). I always get cheated in some ways from the way they look. So perfectly shiny on the outside, you want to take a bite. When you do bite into it your tastebuds don't match what your eyes saw and before you know it you have these weird bits of pork fat making your stomach yelp alittle bit. Never have I had that experience at Lung Fung! The best in the city and their cocktail buns are really yummy too! I can't ever leave the city to visit friends and family without them requesting buns from here. Not sure if that's a good thing or not.
author: gina s.

description: This place has been around as long as I can remember! To me it is considered Outer Richmond's Best Chinese Bakery. I am writing this review now because it I stopped by today and bought some goodies that my grandma used to buy. My grandma used to take my little brother and me here to cha siu bao, sponge cake, dan tat, hot dog buns and cookies. The lady that mans the counter is a sweet old lady that has known me since i was a little boy. This does have its advantages because sometimes she will give me some good deals and I end up saving some money! always a plus! I love the sponge cake from here, although it can be a bit dry, its good with coffee or milk. I also love their Dan Tats, they are flaky and crisp with yummy egg custard in the center. This will forever be one of my favorite bakeries and as i write this and eat dan tat, the flood of childhood memories flow thru my head.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
I love Lung Fung Bakery for sentimental reasons.  It is the smell and taste of my childhood's Sunday morning. I remember Lola Addie picking up a BBQ bun for me to eat on the walk to church "so i can concentrate on my prayers, and not on my stomach". Like many Asian grannies, she believed that anything you do (which in this case was singing in the school choir) is done best with a satisfied tummy. Somehow the 7 block trek to St. Monica's was shorter and less dreary with a fresh-out-of-the-oven bun steaming my cheeks pink and warming my chubby little hands. On the way home, we would buy a box of assorted buns for all the 'sleepyheads' who missed mass. I would always beg Lola for a slice of the chocolate cream roll cake and after much (feigned) consideration, she always agreed to...on the condition that i saved it for dessert. (yeah, right...) 

Flashing back to the present, I wish there was some way to transport this tiny, nondescript bakery over to this side of the Bay. Its no frills appearance oozes with character from the Chinese geriatrics discussing the contents of their newspapers to the banter between the lady who runs the store and the bakers in back. I've tried nearly every Chinese bakery in Oakland and for some reason, I can never find baked goods as delicious as Lung Fung's. The bread is never as light , sweet  and fluffy. The ratios of meat to bread is always disproportionate, and the people serving your order are never as nice as the short haired lady who is queen of this little slice of heaven. 

The last time i stopped in (which was in '02) was to buy a box of goodies to take back to the dorms. She totally remembered me and said (in clipped English)  that i "was so big now" and asked how my grandmother was. I told her she passed away and she looked sad and gave me a slice of chocolate roll cream cake as if in my Lola's honor. Its an absurdly small and seemingly insignificant gesture, but its the heartfelt kind that comes with small businesses that know and appreciate their loyal customers. I haven't been back in years, and writing this post makes me nostalgic for its yummyness. 

Here are my Top 10 Recomendations:

BBQ Pork Bun (baked, not steamed)
Ham and Egg bun-- eggs so perfectly fluffy, its amazing
Ham and Corn bun-- werid combo, i know but it just WORKS...
Cocktail bun-- simple, sweet, delicious
Chicken pie-- its like a mini-chicken pot pie with peas and carrots
Beef Curry Horn-- ground beef & onions in a green curry. YUM!
Pineapple bun
Ham and onion bun
Cream rolls (served as a log or in slices) Choco is my fave, but there is vanilla and strawberry too.
Egg tarts-- not to heavy, just right with the creamy
author: Kris R.

description: 2 words. Cocktail Bun. they're like 25 cents each. i don't even know what's inside it but it is warm, fresh, cheap, and delicious!
author: Shayenne G.

description: I am SOLD!  Best BBQ Pork Buns ON THE PLANET!  I will always get a dozen when I visit my beautiful home town of SF.  Every bite is filled with delicious juicy BBQ pork.  Nothing like it in the world!  5 STARS!
author: Sabrina A.

description: Thank you fellow Yelpers for the very informative and useful reviews on this place! Whenever I crave for baked BBQ pork buns, I drive across the bay to fulfill my craving. Growing up in Vancouver, Canada, I used to think that Newtown Bakery had the best BBQ pork buns but Lung Fung supersedes this place! I prefer the baked buns over steamed ones and appreciate that it's not as fatty as other bakeries. The lady behind the counter is very nice and usually will round off your tab by asking if you'd like to thrown in another bun for a few cents more. These warm buns are so popular that sometimes they have a limited supply and you will not be able to get the quantity desired. It will only make you appreciate every bite till the last crumb.
author: Carmina B.

description: I remember when the BBQ pork buns were 50 cents a piece. Despite the massive inflation, this is still my go to spot for classic Chinese bakery goods.  Been coming here for 20 years, strong. Don't forget to wash it all down with a classic Vita box of mango or guava juice.
author: Alan N.

description:
I have been coming here since I was in elementary school (down the street at Alamo)!!  This place has not changed and neither has the owner who still remembers me after all these years (although I don't know her name she's real nice!!)

My staples here include: 

1- Gai Mae bow (aka "cocktail bun)- buttery richness, fluffy, and oh so good!!

2- Mexican bun- i still have no idea what's up with the name but it basically has the insides from the Gai Mae bow on top of it- that buttery stuff (whatever it is) is a winner!!

3- Pineapple Bun- has a flaky, slightly crispy topping that is supposed to taste like pineapple but tastes like butter to me- bottom line, it's goood!!

4- Strawberry and peach cakes- man, their cakes are light and fluffy- the cream is not too heavy and they load the cakes with fruit!! I've had one of these cakes on at least 10 of my birthdays growing up and I even had one made for my wedding reception in SF - I always dreamed of having one of their cakes for my wedding =P
author: Russ N.

description: Try Egg tart.. I think it was okay. Didn't really have the egg taste of favor.
author: Joyce W.

description: Good. Clean. BBQ bork and egg custard both some of the freshest in town. Very friendly as well
author: Jason G.

description: Whenever I travel through SF on 19th, I stop off and pick up pork buns and other goodies at Lung Fung.  The owner always encourages me to try new things and I'm never disappointed.  I especially like the curry buns and red bean buns and I enjoy that the bakery is always crowded with neighborhood folks playing chess.
author: Kristen L.

description: The best Chinese bakery in the Outer Richmond! They have one of the best BBQ pork buns in the city! The bread is light and airy and the filling is seasoned just right! Every single pastry here is made to perfection and that's a hard thing to do!
author: Brian P.

description: my absolute favorite chinese bakery!!! the dan tat (egg tarts) here are the best, i tried the ones from golden gate bakery in chinatown and those aren't as good as the ones here. all the buns that i have had here are so yummy and fresh.
author: Stella J.

description: The best place for Bolo Buns (Pineapple Buns)! The lady at the counter is so nice.
author: M M.

description: I discovered this place by mistake.. Whoever came into work late had to buy breakfast. So I'm cruising around and I see a parking spot.. I see this funky looking bakery and say.. what the hell... it's a free breakfast for the crew.. they better not bitch. I buy a dozen pork buns and head off to work. OMG... BACSB = Bomb Ass Char Siu Bao! (pork buns) I have had my fair share of good and bad pork buns... but these are the shiznit (ebonics reference for YUMMY) The guys at work all said these were the best pork buns they have ever had. The char siu (bbq pork) inside the bun was cut to the perfect size.. the gravy was the perfect taste and consistency. Gotta try these yourself.. you wont be disappointed.
author: Alan N.

description:
We have tried the Dan Tart (egg custard) all over the Bay area (as well as NYC, Vancouver, and other large cities) and Lung Fung Bakery's DTs are the best!  The crust is always light and fluffy, and the custard is smooth and delicious.  It is especially good when it just comes out of the oven.  We don't know what their secret sauce is, but so far, no one has been able to duplicate it.

Wonderful famly run operation -- don't let the outside appearance fool you.  This is world-class DT!!

Note: Because it is so good, they often sell out early, so if you want some, call ahead and order.  They will put aside an order for you for pickup.
author: M H.

description: As in agreement with everyone else.  This is the best BBQ pork bun i have ever tried.  The egg tart is good.  Cost half of GG bakery in c-town, and doesn't taste half as bad.  Now reading other reviews, i want to try their other selections.  Everything is cheap and the service is fast and friendly.  I even sometimes got an urge to play some chinese chess, i figure getting schooled won't be so bitter with a sweet bun and tart!
author: Quailty P.

description: Update: The egg custards  (dahn tat) are freaking tasty also! AND... they seem to smell more fragrant than the Chinatown-variety. I wonder what the secret ingredient is - my speculation is that it is crack, because this stuff is addicting!
author: Tony L.

description: My family has been getting our cocktail buns, pork buns, sweet egg custard tarts, and custard buns from Lung Fung for about 25 years.  They are absolutely the best and most authentic Chinese bakery in SF.  The woman who is at the counter every day is a ball of sunshine.  Love that lady.  Every time I walk in I can see that she is happy to see me.  I think knowing we have loved her bakery for so many years makes her glow with pride.  We never really talk.  Her English is pretty rough.  But after exchanging smiles and nods, no words are really necessary.  She is happy to bake Chinese treats for me, and I am more than happy to eat them!
author: Kandi K.

description:
Delicious cheap amazing pork, red bean, and pineapple buns.  SF's most delicious 70 cent lunch.

website: http://doublespaaced.blogspot.com/2010/08/richard-yatesetay-drahcir.html
author: dean e.

description: Their egg tarts are awesomely good. this place is jam packed with old Chinese people who come here for tea and cakes, but service is quick.
author: N T.

description: Fantastic pork buns!  Came here from NY and this place puts all the Chinese bakeries in NYC to shame.  The store is not fancy and actually quite shabby.  But, the pork buns reigns.  The bread is light and fluffy and the pork is sweet and sticky and nicely seasoned with the saucy goodness.  Good stuff!
author: Carolyn N.

description: A I went for an early morning walk and came across this bakery. After reading a good majority of the reviews, I had to check this place out for myself.  Not by the very least was I disappointed.   The tastes of the treats this bakery had was great.  The pork buns were definently tasty, reminding me of growing up in SF.  I ended up going back to this place twice to bring some back to SAC.  Decent prices for the food and brought me back to my upbringing.  Will stop again on my next trip to SF.
author: T C.

description: This is one of those establishments where older Chinese men come in and hang out all day playing Chinese checkers. When you enter the bakery, they will holler to the boss lady in the kitchen to let her know someone is here to make a purchase. I have to admit, I've been living in the inner Richmond 3.5 years now, and only ventured into Lung Fung Bakery this past August. But it's definitely one of my favorite places to go and buy egg custard tarts. I'm lucky, I always get them piping hot and fresh, and OMG they're so good!!! I can see why fellow yelpers venture from all corners of the city to buy their baked goodies here. The BBQ buns are also very yummy. We don't always make it past Park Presidio, but when we're heading out that way, the egg custard tarts at Lung Fung is the one of the few places that makes my ever mellow hubbie excited.
author: Annie Y.

description: Yummy is the first word that comes to mind when I think of Lung Fung Bakery.  They have arguably the best char sui bows (bbq pork buns) in San Francisco.  Juicy, moist, flavorful, on the inside and golden brown, honey glazed, baked to perfection goodness on the outside.  Sooooooooooooooo good!  This place is a must try if you like char sui bows.
author: Phil Y.

description: This place has great baked pork buns. The bread  is nice and soft with just a hint of sweet to it. The bbq pork filling is luscious and not too fatty. The other baked items: pineapple bun, dinner roll, egg tarts, green onion roll, mini chicken pot pies,hot dog baked in a roll and ham & egg roll are tasty as well. But this place is known for their baked pork buns. They do nice and light tasting birthday cakes too.  Most of the individual baked goods are priced at 70 cents or less. The one turn off is having to walk through the cloud of cigarette smoke to get inside the bakery. The morning patrons are all major smokers.
author: cyndi L.

description:
I love this place.
They are the only place that knows how to make a good sponge cake.
The one I'm talking about is kind of long, has a slightly bulbous top and has four pieces of paper around it that you peel away.
It's so moist on the inside.
I grew up eating everything this place has to offer.
And in my 30 years, the quality has never changed.
author: chibi i.

description: Hands down the best chao su bao I have ever had. My father goes by on the regular to pick up these delicious pork buns, two-dozen at a time, and our friends request that we bring them to all parties and social gatherings we attend. If this place sold nothing else, I would not be sad, because the bao are really that extraordinary. They look just all others, they taste so much better. Oh, the individual sponge cakes are good, too, and the onion bread is disgustingly delicious and creamy, but it's all about the bao. And dang, you can't beat the price, they're practically giving them away.
author: Marie S.

description: Best pork buns i've had. period
author: Hugh L.

description:
my family and i have been coming here since the 80's and have been loyal customers since.. everything here is amazing... especially their CAKES. light, fluffy and flavorful.. 

dont waste your time with the other crap on clement.
author: Dave N.

description: I have only eaten curry beef buns at this bakery, but that's enough: they are flakey and light, and thus I avoid the dreaded Chinese bun syndrome, after which I feel so full that I can't eat for three hours.  I definitely want to try more of their baked goods, though.
author: Raphael R.

description: The egg tarts were really good here. The lady behind the counter was really nice and even brought out hot fresh egg tarts for me from the back. 5 stars for the service and fresh egg tarts :]
author: X F.

description: We walked over here after having dim sum at Hong Kong Lounge, Thursday December 23 around noon -- only to find the bakery completely empty.  Cases empty, no food to be seen anywhere, no people, lights off, but door wide open.  Very puzzling.
author: K L.

description: Hands down best cocktail buns and baked char siu bao in SF, and believe me,during the 2 months I lived in SF this year, I was definitely on the hunt. I think it's hilarious how the lady always tries to get me to buy more than what I ordered by giving me a little discount.  I have a weakness for Chinese pastries, so I usually cave in.
author: Jen S.

description: I was looking for some great egg tarts. So I did some research and went to Lung Fung Bakery. I loved it! Just out of the oven... perfect.The lady at the counter is super friendly and offered me some coconut buns (delicious!!!) and Moon Cakes. I will go back for a catering order!!!
author: Gisela D.

description: I come here at least a few times a week for baked BBQ pork puns, cocktail buns (only 50 cents!), chicken pies, or pineapple custard buns.
author: Tyler L.

description: I feel like I'm in heaven with every bite of the fresh, steamy, soft pork bun that this bakery is known for... trust me, one bite and you'll be hooked!!  The egg tart is also delicious, and I think it makes a perfect snack in the middle of the day!
author: Karina L.

description: Around the corner from my cozy dwelling, sits an oven that just won't stop popping out dozens of savory stuffed buns throughout the day, and it's a good thing too because there would be a crowd of disappointed patrons outside throwing rocks if this place were to run out of PORK BUNS!!!  OK, maybe not a crowd, maybe just me! In all my years (which aren't too many), I have never had such a pleasurable experience eating a pork bun before. The light crisp of the glazed top, the chopped pork drowned in warm gooey sauce and the softness of the bread, has me wiggling all the way home every Sunday!
author: Deanna T.

description:
This is my favorite place to get Chinese buns! Their buns are fresh and warm, unlike MANY of the bakeries in the sunset.  

Their cocktail buns are so soft, sweet and buttery.  It melts in your mouth.  The egg tarts are also really good.  They are so fresh.  Too bad I don't live that close by anymore. I used to buy boxes for Friday breakfast at work. EVERYONE, even those who normally did not eat Chinese buns, loved the buns and egg tarts! 

The owner is very nice!
author: vernice l.

description: omg - cocktail buns at $.50 a pop!  warm, sweet, sugary deliciousness - it is hard to stop at one.  AND served to you with a smile :)
author: shannon j.

description: We found this place by asking someone on the street what is the best bakery place around San Francisco.   We were so happy that we found this place...their barbeque pork bums and cocktail bums are the best I have ever tested.  Even though we live in the east bay, we come here often just to pick up some bread from this place.
author: Elena H.

description: Love this place for the warm buns....they always look fresh. The lady behind the counter is super nice and has a big smile on her face. I never know what to get, but she always suggests one of the buns in the warming oven. Yummy! I walk out a happy lady with either the cocktail bun or pork bun....I just wish they had the steamed kind too!
author: Camille B.

description: Okay all these rave reviews got me to write my first review on Yelp.  I'd just like to say WAY overrated!  BBQ Pork Buns?  I've had better and bigger.  The meat was also a little overly sweet with more sauce than actual solid pork chunks.  Those who say the egg tarts are better than Golden Gates gotta get yourselves some new taste buds cuz these egg tarts were total duds!  The tarts didn't have much eggy custardy flavor, and had a mushy crust.  I wouldn't ever eat them here again.  Gold Gate Egg Tarts are LEAGUES better than these.  They shouldn't even be mentioned in the same breath!  The Pineapple buns? Not enough crusty goodness up top and not much buttery flavor.  The only thing I'd come back here for is the Chicken Tail Buns.  Those had a very nice rich filling and didn't have too much coarse overpowering coconut shreds like many other places.  Plus there's not too much extra bread at the ends like some places.  Other folks might like the coconut but I don't so I find these Chicken Tail buns to be quite good.  Will I come back here for those maybe and to try the redbean buns which they ran out of when I went.
author: Frank C.

description:
for my late lunch today, i went on a random drive.  while scanning my brain for spots on my newly discovered yelp, and thinking i was going to end up someplace downtown, i was presented with a very convenient parking spot on geary and 20th.  now i have had issues with losing opportunities which have presented themselves recently, and so, i wanted to show the universe to keep them coming because i won't hesitate any longer.  if this was a test, i was eager to pass and see what awaits.
so my random drive turned into a random stroll.  i was very close to abandoning mission when the sensous aroma of freshly baked goods was found wafting in the air.  the pavlovian instinct kicked in as i honed in on the source.

upon entering this bakery, i tried to exercise restraint and ordered only the bbq pork bun, which was a meager 80 cents.  the nice young lady advised i try the custard tart, which just came out of the oven, and therefore was the culprit which brought me in.  the bbq pork bun was probably the best i've ever had - the bread was warm, slightly crisp on the outside, and perfectly moist on the inside.  the pork was equally impressive as it wasn't too sweet and was bathed in a tasty brown bbq sauce.  dude.  omg and abcdefg...  at this point, it didn't matter what the custard tart was like, that bbq bun brought me to a hedonistic zone.  but as quickly as it disappeared, the custard tart arrived at my palate, and right now i must refrain from thinking about it too much because i'll have to run out and get some more.  in the meantime, i need a cigarette.  wait, i don't smoke - i'll take another custard tart instead.

as the kids say, these goods were "the bomb diggity, dog".

for now 4 stars, only because i initially didn't see alot of variety, but this may be changed to 5 after a few more visits (and pork buns!)
author: Ed S.

description: This place has been my mom's favorite BBQ pork bun place for years. We always order dozens upon dozens to bring to our relatives out of town, and none of them ever go to waste. It's my favorite place for pineapple buns, and it helps that the woman who owns the place is super sweet.
author: Tami H.

description: My family and relatives have been ordering birthday cakes from here for a long time.  This is a lot of people I'm talking about.  Everyone in my family knows Lung Fung cakes from other cakes.  They have the best cake and the best service!  The lady (owner?) always has a smile on her face.  The pricing is decent and the baking goods takes soooooooo good!
author: Linda H.

description: This is in a good location, you don't have to wait too long in line like some places, parking is easy, the buns are delicious and freshly baked, open 7 days a week, and the service is superior! Definitely adds a great start to the day!
author: Jennifer W.
